div.p: A TRIVMPH OF TRVTH.
OR Declaration of the doctrine concerning EVANGELICALL COVNSAYLES; lately deliuered in OXFORD by HVMFREY LEECH M. of Arts, & Minister.
WITH Relation of sondry occurrents, and particularly of D. KING, the Vicechancellour, his exorbitant proceedings against the sayd H. L. vpon his constant propugnation thereof.
ALSO The peculiar MOTIVES, ensuing therevpon, which perswaded him to renounce the faction of hereticall Congregations, & to embrace the vnity of the CATHOLIQVE Church.
div.q: Great is the TRVTH, and prevayleth. 3. Esdr. 4.41.
div.p: M.D.C.IX.

div.head: TO THE LEARNED, WISE, AND INGENIOVS ACADEMICKS FLOVRISHING IN THE RENOWNED VNIVERSITY OF OXFORD.
div.p: EXPERIENCE doth wel approoue S. Bernards saying; Efficacior lingua, quàm litera: the tongue is of greater efficacie, then the • pen. And therfore I suffer no little disaduantage, in that I must now speake vnto you in a silent letter, and plead my cause by a mute aduocate of my minde.

But since I vvrite vnto them, vvho are • ot strangers in my busines, but aswell • ye vvitnesses of the vvronges, vvhich I • aue endured, as eare vvitnesses of the Doctrine, vvhich I preached amongst • ou; my vndoubted hope is, that your
heartes wil be touched with some compassion either tovvards me, vnvvorthily intreated by a faction (for I will not impute the crime of a fevv vnto all) or tovvards your selues, vvhom this particular doth very highly import, in respect of your learning, honour, and estimation.

For as the iniurie, which God, and his truth haue sustayned in my person, is now made knowne not only vnto our nation, but the fame thereof beginneth to spread it self abroad in theis forayne parts, so it concerneth you (my louing Fathers, and Brethren) to vvype avvay that disgrace, and blemish from your Mother, and your selues, vvhich some of her vnnaturall Children vvould both stayne her vvith, and deriue vpon you; endeuouring to obscure their priuate folly in the publick shame. VVhich protection I vvil neuer afford vnto them, vnlesse they can obtayn it by your ovvne consent.

VVherefore, out of my affectionate zeale vnto your credit, I do both humbly desire, and earnestly require you to auert this infamy from your noble Mother, and to free hir from the imputation, vvhich, othervvayes, you dravv vpon hir, as being eyther a patronesse of falsehood, or fearfull to defend the truth: vvhich folly in the first, or pusillanimity in the second, is a great stayne vnto men of your quality, and place.

For you stile your Vniuersitie the Fountayn, and the Eye of the kingdome. And you say not vnfitly; forasmuch as the Doctrine there taught doth streame forth into all parts of our nation: and all men come vnto you to receiue information of their vnderstandings, by your Academicall instruction.

In vvhich respect you stand deepely obliged vnto God, and men (as you haue care of his glorie, and their benefitt) to vindicate the truth from oppression, & to redeeme hir out of captiuitie into
freedome, that hir lustre may not be darkened, vvhere so great a pretense is made of the ghospells light.

Which iust kindnesse if I may not procure at your hands, yet the truth shall not be impayred thereby: nor vvill I be any vvhitt discōfited, othervvayes then in a sorrowfull commiseration of your estate. For my resolution is firmely made vvithin mine ovvne heart, to spare no travayle, that I may purchase condigne approbation of my cause from all the Vniuersities in Europe: if iustice may not be there done, vvhere Gods truth, and I (meerely for hir sake) haue receiued such iniurie, as seemeth almost incredible vnto strangers, vvho do not yet sufficientlie vnderstād the courses of D. King, and of other Caluinists; the assistents of his spleneticall proceedings.

Finally (my Brethren) vvith my honest petition, and necessarie counsaill, I ioyne my hearty praiers (and teares vvith them) that it vvould please the authour
of all goodnesse, and the God of all truth, to povvre the abundant riches of his grace into your soules, that your vnderstandings may be fully enlightened vvith his truth, and that your vvills may be made cōformable therevnto in your profession of the holy Catholicke faith. For vvhich as I novv suffer the vvant of my natiue cōtrey, so, in defence thereof, I shall be ready to yeald vp my life, vvhē it shall please my gratious Lord to call me vnto that honour: vvhereof I am vnvvorthy.

closer.signed: Your deuoted Brother in Christ. Humfrey Leech.

IIII. The Protestants subuert the truest meanes of piety, and deuotion.

div.p: In the conclusion of this Treatise, ensue the testimonies of the Greeke, and Latin Fathers, concerning Euangelicall Counsayles; vvith an Aduertisement to the Reader.

div.head: THE PREFACE vnto the vvhole discourse.
div.p: WHEN I first set footing into this present businesse, my purpose vvas not (no not in my most secret thoughts) to enter into any point of controuersie, or to giue occasion of offence, or dislike vnto any: only my resolution vvas, plainely, and positiuely (as the course of my studies had euer bent, and caried me) to glaunce at a mayne point of doctrine (it comming but obiter in my vvay) directly vvarranted, nay lineally deduced frō the vniforme consent of all ancient times; bequeathed vnto vs by the perpetuall tradition, and practise of the Church.

But yet since, contrary to my probable persuasion, certaine priuate spirits (vvhose faith is their ovvne fancy) ytching rather after prophane nouelty, and hereticall innouation,
thē abiding the vvholsome doctrine of sacred Antiquity, and the Churches dogmaticall tradition, haue, by all meanes, laboured to impugne my doctrine, and to defame my person: I haue thought my selfe in conscience, and duty (both before God, and man) obliged, asvvell for the generall satisfaction of all, vvhom this present businesse may any vvay concerne, as for my ovvne dischardge in particular (being the party herein especially interessed) briefly to compile, and publish the vvhole cariadge, and progresse of this matter, in the ensuing treatise; humbly recōmending, and euer submitting my opinion vnto the graue, and infallible iudgmēt of the Church, at vvhose feete, and tribunall alone prostrating my selfe, J must stand, or fall: as also referring my self, vvith the moderate deportment of my cause, vnto the syncere iudgement of the discreete, and impartiall Reader.

THE FIRST PART Contayning my entrance into the doctrine of Euangelicall Counsayles vvith my defence of the same agains • the secret murmuratiō of the Brethre •

div.head: A TRIVMPH OF TRVTH. OR DECLARATION OF THE DOCTRINE CONCERNING EVANGELICALL COVNSAYLES;
CHAP. I. The first ingresse into the doctrine of EVANGELICALL COVNSAYLES.
div.p: INTREATING of this parcell of holy scripture; I savv the dead, In a Sermon at Christs-Church in Oxford 1607 Apocal. 20.12. both great, and small, stand before God; I distinguished a fourefould acception, or signification of great, and small. FIRST; great, and small for worldly authority, & temporal condition. SECONDLY; great, and small in respect of heauenly supereminency of grace, and spirituall infusion. THIRDLY; great and small in lieu of diuersity of rewards, and retribution. FOVRTHLY; great, and small in regard of contrariety, and disparity of workes, and operation.

Moral. li. 26. cap. 24. 25.Hereunto I applied that distinction of S. GREGORY; Quidam iudicantur, & pereunt: quidam non iudicātur, & pereunt: quidam iudicantur, & regnant: quidam non iudicantur, & regnant. That is (as another ancient writer, somewhat varying the wordes, but keeping the sense, doth excellently render it) some are to be iudged, and damned; perishing by iudgment. Some are iudged, & damned already; perishing vvithout iudgement. Some are to be iudged & saued; saued vvith iudgment. Some are iudged and saued allready; saued vvithout iudgment. And all this diuersity of iudgment ariseth from contrariety, and disparity of workes, acted, and done here in this life, by great and small mentioned in my text.

This distinction I breifly dilated vpon, as the straightnesse of time (which now had ouertaken me) would giue me leaue, and cōming to the last member of the distinction, in the very close, and vpshot of the sermon, I concluded, that those, who were to be saued vvithout iudgment, are such, as did transcend the precepts of the law by due performance of EVANGELICALL COVNSAYLES of perfection; endeauouring not only to performe the moral obligatory decalogue, but thirsting after more eminent perfection added, nay voluntarily by power of an arbitrary choyce, offered vnto
the lawgiuer more, then the generall precepts of the law necessarily tyed them vnto; deuoting, and consecrating themselues vnto the heauenly profession of spirituall Pouertie, Angelical Chastity, and humble Obedience, renouncing their owne will, forgoing carnall concupiscence, forsaking all thinges, yea and themselues, for Christ, and heauens sake. That is to say; they despise the worlds transitory trashe, and pleasures; and only thirst after spirituall goods, which are the true treasure of heauen.

This was the summe, and substance deliuered in my first entrance into this point, M. Doctour KINGE (vicechancellour of the vniuersity) being then present; and giuing no signification of dislike conceyued by him against the verity of this doctrine.

div.head: CHAP. II. Hovv vpon the vicechancellours silence, the BRETHREN murmured secretely against the aforesayd doctrine.
div.p:
NOw let the indifferent, and iudicious Reader obserue, whether I may not more then probably conclude, that either the vicechancellour, at this time, apprehended it not; or apprehending it, in his owne true iudgment,
and conscience disgusted it not; or distasting it, yet being not able to conuince, and refell the demonstratiue euidence of it, could haue bene content to winke at it, and giue it his indulgent cōniuency, so that it might thus haue passed away in silence.

Was the point erroneous? where then was his iudgment, that should haue descried it, if it deserued his censure? why escaped it then vnrebuked? might this doctrine now passe currant, and must it afterwards be iudged counterfaict? In a word: is the doctrine as it was generally intimated, allowable; and are the particulars therof being now dilated, and amplified, made thereupon intollerable?

Howbeit certaine of a purer strayne (BRETHREN some men call them; and Brethren I confesse them to be; fratres in malo, as Simeo •
and Leui sometimes were) secretly murmured, and beganne in corners priuately (as Heretiques vsually haue done) to traduce me, my doctrine, and my authour S. GREGORY: calumniating that in secrete, which openly the • durst not yet aduenture substantially to impugne.

The report, and rumour wherof (by relation of some frends) no sooner came vnto m • eares, but presently (knowing well the assure • grounds of my doctrine) I addressed my self •
to haue satisfied, & contented any ingenious, and vnpassionate auditour, by a second repetition, with a briefe, punctuall, and perspicuous explanation & confirmation of my aforesayd doctrine: For I was alltogether vnwilling to suffer the least imputation or scandall to be fastened vpon it, or vpon the Authour (were it but in corners secretly) and farther, though I intended not to runne into a publick opposition, yet now occasion might be ministred vnto me, and others to vindicate a necessary truth from the detraction of calumnious tongues.

div.head: CHAP. III. Hovv the former doctrine vvas illustrated, vpon the BRETHRENS priuate calumniation therof.
div.p:
BEING thus occasioned by the secrete, & clancular murmuration of Brethren (the fame wherof beganne now to disperse it selfe abroad) to addresse some defence of my former doctrine; I tooke the next opportunity to supply the publique place, and willing rather to giue a little further touch to conuince the sayd Brethren, then to dwell, as yet, vpon any mayne, and full discourse (which was not my
purpose; the point being yet not publickly contradicted) I repeated, and dilated vpon th • point more at lardge; as it was originally deduced out of the last branch of S. GREGOR • his distinction; to wit, quidam non iudicantu • & regnant: to this purport, and effect.

Of this point (sayd I) I may speake as S. Ioh •
speaketh to the seauen Churches of Asia; co •
cluding euer the burthen of his admonitio • with a patheticall epiphonema in the reprehension; Let him that hath an eare to heare, heare vvh • the spirit saith to the Churches. And may not apply; let him that hath not only an eare to heare, b • a soule to saue by the eares hearing, heare wha • the celestiall oracle, heauenly spirit, and C •
tholique Church ioyntly speake, and deliu • concerning EVANGELICALL COVNSAILE •

Or I may speake with our blessed Sauiou • aduising, exhorting, counsayling, yea, out • the whole masse of mankind, inuiting, nay i • citing some to that angelicall gift of virgina • chastity;Math. 19.12. qui potest capere, capiat; he that can a •
pire to the toppe of angelicall integrity, l • him become a votary of virginall Chastity.

This is S. Paul his sapientia inter perfectos; ap •
stolicall wisedome for men of angelicall pe •
fection. These easily disclose, and discouer th • worlds foolishenes & impostures, when the paragon them with heauens remuneratiō, an •
treasures. These are the salt of the earth, and the light of the vvorld: starres fixed in the spheare of heauen, the Church militant; not wandring in their motion towards heauen, the Church triumphant.

These are our best pilotts amongst men; their godly conuersation ought to be our holy imitation. These guide by their examples the barkes of our bodies (wherin the eternall treasures of our soules are caried, as in earthen vessells) through the perilous rockes of the seas of this worlde, that they may ariue safely at the designed hauen of heauen, when they flitt from the bedd of this mortall body.

These are beacons on a hill (the hill of the Church) whose liues as lightes, and burning lamps, forewarne, and so forearme vs against all inuasion of any spirituall enimies. These are entia trascendentia men foaring aboue the ordinary pitch of men, celestial men, terrestial Angels, surmounting and transcending the precepts of the law by Euangelicall Counsayles of perfection: endeuouring not only to performe the law, but thirsting after a more holy, heauenly, and excelling perfection, haue pe • formed more then the lawes generall precepts obliged them vnto; adding ouer, & aboue the law, that which the law wanted of the merit of perfection; as S. BASILL speaketh; professing
spirituall pouerty, De vera virginitate prope finem. angelicall Chastity, and humble obedience; and all this for heauens sake.

And that they may more readily follow, and deuoutly adhere vnto Christ they cast away that which presseth dovvne so fast, nay which often times presseth downe to hell; ouerloading, and surcharging the soule with immoderate weight; the thorny cares, and choking ryches of this present worlde.

These with feare and trembling recompt, & remember that terrible interrogation of out Sauiour concerning the worlds riches, & the profit redounding vnto man in the vayne, and maine pursuite therof; vvhat shal it aduantage • man to winne the vvhole vvorld, & to loose his owne soule?

And therfore these professors of Euangelical Counsayles, merchandising for their soules earnestly with al spiritual endeuour vpon the seas of this world, follow the counsayle, which Christ gaue to the yong man (who came to 〈◊〉 the WAY to learne the way to heauen) if tho • vvilt be perfit, go sell all that thou hast, and giue t • the poore, and thou shalt haue treasure in heauen, an • come and folovv me.

O what an exchāge had this yoūg man made what an offer did Christ make him, wha • Counsaile did the wisdome of the father giue him, how much doth it now repent him? In •
word: ô how happy had he bene, both in body and in soule, since he had bene secure of the saluation both of body, and of soule, and not only secure of that, but thesaurum habuisset in coelo, his pennie had bene of pure gould, and he had had measure for measure, yea aboue measure, heauens remuneration heaped vpon him in lieu of Christian perfection, if he had parted with him selfe, and abandoned the worlds trashe, to haue partaked with Christ, and heauens treasure.

And yet this being a counsayle not a precept, it is not enioyned as a precept to all, but giuen by way of counsayle vnto perfiter men, as the fathers teache. And the reason is excellently rendred by S. GREGORY the great, to be this. It is not enioyned as a precept to all (for then vvere it sinne either to marry, or to possesse any of the vvorlds goods) but yet it is counsayled vnto men of more holy ranke; For these haue an arbitrary, and voluntary choyce in their things.
Such were the Apostles, and those Apostolicall men, that hauing possessiōs, sould them, brought in the money and layde it downe at the Apostles feete.Act. 4.

Such was holy Antony that ancient Monke of Egypt; S. Paul the Heremite; S. Benedict; S. Hierom; S. Basill; S. Gregory Nazianzen; S. Gregory the great; S. Bernard, and many other
Doctours, and Fathers; the most renowned lights of learning, and greatest pillars of the Church.

And was not Christ him selfe Maister, and Regius Professor of this spirituall poverty? spirituall I call it, because the contempt of this world for the hope of heauen, is the worke of Gods spirit, wrought within our soules. Witnesse his entrance into this world, when his house was a stable, his cradle a cratch; witnesse his continuance in the world, lyuing mearely vpon almes ministred vnto him by certaine godly women, and deuout persons. VVitnesse his complaint; the foxes haue holes, and the birds of heauen haue nests, but the sonne of man hath not, vvhereon to rest his head. And was he any richer at his departure out of this worlde, when wanting a sepulcher of his owne, he was enterred in an other mans tombe?

Finally; though he were lord, and owner of all (being God the lord, and creator of all) and the sole heyre-apparant of heauen, and earth; yet was he content to forsake all: of rich he became poore, teaching aswell opere, as ore, by example of lyuing, as manner of teaching; reall practising,Act. 1. as orall instructing; first doing, & then teaching; and all to this end, vt conuersatio magistri forma esset discipuli; as blessed LEO speaketh;Ser. 5. de Na
•• uit. Christi. that is, that he might generally
weane all Christians from the loue of this world; but especially, that he might become vnto his disciples, and all Apostolicall men, a perfit patterne of this spirituall poverty; the maisters conuersation being the schollers best instruction.

For Christ came not downe from heauen to earth, from the bosome of the Father, by his eternall generation, GOD, to the wombe of his Mother, by temporall incarnation, MAN; when he deigned to stoope downe so lowe, nay vouchafed exinanire seipsum, to put of the garment of his Fathers, and heauens glory, inuesting his incomprehensible deity with the base raggs of finite mortality; I say Christ did not performe all this onely to fulfill the morall Decalogue, but ouer, and aboue the lawes righteousnesse, he taught that,See S. Basill. de vera virginit. which the law wanted of the merit of perfection.

And as he taught this vnto vs by practise in his owne most sacred person, and in the persons of his Apostles, so he left vs the first pure primitiue Church, and raysed vp many in the other succeeding ages and Centuries of the Catholique Church, to be examples, and patternes of these Euangelicall Counsayles.

This was the summe of my Repetition, with a more ample explanation of my former Doctrine; iustified now in publique against the
Brethren, who had traduced it in their whispering conuenticles, according to the liberty of their priuate spiritts.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. D. HVTTON his kitchin-conference vvith me vpon the deliuery of this last sermon.
div.p: THIS sermon being ended, and supper time immediately approaching; M. Doctour Hutton (one of the Channons of Christ-Church; now deputed Prouicechancellour in the absence of M. Doctour King) sent for me by one of my fellow Chaplaines into the cōmon kitchin,A place fitt to treat vpō Iouinianisme; but vnfit for the sacred mysteries of Religion. to conferre with me vpon the point deliuered in my sermon.

Hither I no sooner came, but, he (interessing himselfe in the quarrell of IOVINIAN) beganne very fiercely to assault, & chardge me for preaching scandalous, & erroneous doctrine; excepting farther against the termes of Angelicall Chastity, and Euangelicall Counsailes of perfection; expressely mentioned by me in the aforesaid sermon.

The onset being thus giuen by his worshipp, my warde was; Sir. (vnder your correction) the doctrine lately by me preached (howsoeuer
you disconceipt it) is not, nay cannot possibly be either scandalous, or erroneous; for it is the doctrine of that great Pillar of the Latine Church S. Gregory; accorded vnto, and confirmed by vniforme consent of fathers, both of the Greeke and Latine Church.

As for the termes ofVigrinity equalleth it selfe to Angells; yea, if vve examine vvell the matter, vve shall find it to exceede Angells; for that cōtrary to nature, it getteth a victory in flesh aboue flesh, vvhich Angels do not. Cypr. de bono pudicitiae Angelicall Chastity; & Euangelicall Counsailes of perfection, I haue not hammered them vpon any anuile in the forge of my owne braine, but rather borrowed them from Orthodox Antiquity.

Against this he replyed;Virginity (an Angelicall guift) exceedeth matrimony, asmuch as an Angell excelleth a man. Damasc. li. 4. Orthodoxae fidei, cap. 25. Vide Cypr. de natiuitate Christi & Hieron. lib. 1. contra Iouinian. that if I preached any erroneous doctrine out of S. Gregory (such as this must needes be) then both the defence of the doctrine, and Authour himselfe would be required at my hands. For (sayd he) cannot Gregory haue his errours, but you must broach them here to infect this place with POPERY?

This was the accompte, that the culinarian Doctour made of S. GREGORY the great; one of the holiest, & learnedst doctours, that euer breathed in the CATHOLIQVE Church;Ildephonse de viris illustribus ca. 1. Isidore de viris illustribus cap. 2. Vide Greg. Turon. lib. 20. Histor. de laudibuat Gregorij. excelling S. Antony in holinesse, S. Cyprian in eloquēce, S. Augustin in wisedome; ful of cōpunctiō, humility, the grace & feare of God; indued with such light of knowledge, that not any of the present time was equal vnto, no nor of the former: to whose moral expositiō of scripture all the doctours giue place, & that in the
iudgment of a generall councell.

Concilium Toletan.Did it then become M. Doctour HVTTON to detract from the due worth of so great, & learned a Saint? since I may yet adde this to perfit his prayse; vvhatsoeuer he vvas vnto others, doubtlesse vnto vs he vvas an Apostle (to speake in the phrase of the Apostle) to whom our ENLISH nation standeth perpetually obliged for her cōuersion from Paganisme vnto the Christian faith.Beda, Ecclesiast. Histor. Angl. lib. 2. cap. 1.

But to passe ouer the praise of this bright shininge starre in the firmamēt of the Church; my reioynder was, that this doctrine must first be prooued to be erroneous & scandalous before any such imputation ought (vppon absolute necessity) to be imposed, and fastened vpon it, since scandall doth arise from errour, & errour is an approbation of that, which is false in iudgment, and vnderstanding.

And as for defending of S. Gregory, my opinion then was, & now is, that the very name, it self, & Authority of this worthy Father ought and would rather (amongst all learned, and iudicious deuines) be my iust defence and full dischardge, then that his credit should be so farre called into questiō, as now (after a 1000. yeares continuance in the Catholique Church of Christ: being generally reputed Orthodox so longe) to stand in need of myne, or any other
manns defence whatsoeuer.

And yet rather then the doctrine shal be thus odiously traduced, and my Authour want his promerited defence, I will according to that poore ability (wherwith God hath ēabled me) endeuour to defend both it, & him: and therfore if S. Gregory, in this point, hath not transgressed the bounds of ANCIENTER Church, nor crossed any tenent of his owne PRESENT Church, nor yet, for this, hath hitherto bene censured by the laufull iudgement of any Catholique SVCCEDING Church: nay if the Church more ancient then his, his owne present, & the euer after succeding Centuries of Catholique Church haue, from hand to hand, deliuered vnto him, receaued with him, and with vniforme consent followed him in this point of doctrine, neuer so much as once noting it, questioning it, impugning it, contradicting it (which certainly they would haue done, had the doctrine bene erroneous: for their deuoted piety spared no Heretick,Origē Mill •
nar; Tertull. Mōtanising Cypr. rebaptising. no not the moste renowned martirs, nor glorious fathers of the Church in any of their errours, repugnāt vnto the vnity of Catholique verity) then, vpon these premises, I may irrefragably conclude in defence of my Authour, and doctrine, that S. Gregory his position is no priuate opinion hatched out of his owne brayne, but
the vniforme deduction, & tradition of Chri • his spouse the true Catholique, neuer errin • Churche inspired, guided, & directed by Go • his holy spirit in all ages.

But M. Doctour Hutton lending a deafe ea • vnto my defence (though in my conscience and iudgment, it ought to haue satisfied him sounded another alarome, and ringed a fre • peale in my eares, chardging, nay surchar •
ging me (ad nauseam vsque) for houlding an • distinction betwixt PRECEPTS and COVNSAILES. For (said he) there is no such distinction: those, which you falsely call Counsayle •
are in deede Precepts and not Counsayles.

And this was his definitiue resolution, sifting out of the sieue of the Church all th • wheaten meale, I meane the fine flower of sp •
rituall Pouerty, Angelicall Chastity, and leauin • nought else within it, but the branne, and hu •
kes of Iouinian his heresy; which (to speake o • it in one word, as it deserueth) is the very euacuation, & exinanition of all the best fruicte of our Christian Religion. And this he di • with an earnest protestation; not being able t • containe him selfe from vowing, & solemne • swearing before God, that he would send me v • to my Lorde Bishoppe of London, to answer the point before the highe Commission.

To this I replied. Syr: the distinctiō betwix •
Precepts, & Counsailes is no deuise of mine, but the doctrine of S. Paul, grounded vpon Christ his restrictiue negatiue; non omnes capiūt: wherevpon S. Paul had no precept: and vpon Christ his exhortatiue affirmatiue, qui potest capere, capiat. 1. Cor. 7.2 • . Hereupon the Apostle giueth his counsayle; Consilium do: & thus all ancient Church hath interpreted his sentence.

But admit (by way of supposition) your peremptory conclusion, & suppose that there be no counsayles, but let all be precepts; do they not then as PRECEPTS bind you, and that sub poenâ? For that which is a precept is commaunded; that which is cōmaunded, must be done of necessity; that, which must perforce be done, is punished being left vndone: and in vaine is that commaunded as necessary, which is left in the free choyce of the commaunded as voluntary as S. Hierome teacheth.lib. 1 contra Iouinianu. wherefore giue me leaue (without offence) to demaund; why do you, or any other marry, or possesse any of the worlds goods? ought your practise to be cōtrary to the precept? And doth not S. Gregory teache, that if counsailes were precepts, then were it sinne, & that damnable too, to possesse any of the worlds goods? And were not mariadge taken away (which is no lesse then flatt heresy) if virginity were a precept?De vera virg. as S. Basill and the Fathers teach.
This I demanded; but he then passed it oue • with silence; & therefore I expect his answere nou, how he can avoyd this consequence which followeth vpon his owne learning.

As for sending me vpp to London, to answere the point there, my reply was; that, for m • part, I was ready to answere vnto the point and to iustify the doctrine either there, or els • where in what consistory soeuer in the kingdome. Onely for your owne credit sake, an • place (sayd I) which you supply, I wish that i • would please you to be better aduised; at leas • to conferre with some other doctours, wh • heard the sermon aswell as your selfe, and maturely to deliberate, whether there be scandalum datum, or acceptum, a scandall on my par • iustly giuen, or on your part vniustly taken; & whether your exception against my doctrin • will beare waight, or no, being poysed in a • indifferent ballance of equity; before you resolue vpon this precipitation. Otherwayes you shall bewray great want of sound iudgement in opinion, and disclose much ouersigh • in discretion.

And farther; I assure you; call me whithe • you will into question, I shall discardge my se • with sufficient credit, when you shall gayn • little by questioning my doctrine or molestin • me causelesly.

Here the kitchin-conference brake vp: onely, in the loose, he required a copy of that doctrine of Counsailes deliuered by me out of S. Gregory. To this I voluntarily cōdescended: adding these words to intimate my confident resolution. Sir. For the doctrine, I vvill request no favour at your hands: only I hope that you vvill do me iustice: if not, assure your selfe, I shall right my selfe elsevvhere. This was the last period of our conference at that time: & so we parted: supper calling vs both away.

div.head: CHAP. V. Hovv D. Hutton, receyuing a copy of the aforesayd Sermon, found no matter of exception against me. His precipitate course hindered by the aduise of a learned, and iudicious Deuine.
div.p: SOME two dayes following (vpon the very point of the prefixed time, which doctour Hutton had appointed) I deliuered vnto him • in his owne lodging) a punctuall summe, & copy of the doctrine, so vehemently by him excepted against, and so earnestly required.

The said copy, with all seeming alacrity he chearfully, and contentedly receiued at my
hands, dismissing me without any further questioning about the point, either then or any other time after. VVherupon I concluded, that he had retracted his former opinion, by a more prudent circumspection.

And that he now determined to pursue me no farther, I was then, and am now the rather induced to belieue, because, on the very night of our sayd kitchin-conference, he repayred vnto a very graue, and learned Doctour in that Vniuersity (who had heard my sermon) to craue his opinion, and resolution concerning the point; complayning first of my peremptory, and obstinate resolution; discouering withall his disgust of the Doctrine; certifying him farther of his purpose to send me vp to the Bishoppe of London to answere the point there.

The venerable Doctour perceauing his headdy resolution, and withall conceiuing the truth of the Doctrine (which his discreete and mature iudgment could not possibly suffer him to dissemble) very prudently, and learnedly aduised him to stirre no more in the point; but to passe it ouer with a calme, and quiet silence. For (said he) in sending him vppe to London, well you may put him to trouble and chardge: but for the Doctrine (for ought that I could conceiue) the issue
will be this: he may, and will answere it either here, there, or else where, with more credit, then you shall possibly gayne in calling it into question.

And is this (sayd he) the rewarde of our pulpit paynes? Are schollers, whose state you know to be but meane, to be put by schollers vnto this extraordinary chardge, needelesse, and causelesse expense? Ought not you, and I, and all of our ranke, rather study to giue them all lawfull content, then to seeke their greiuances, by surmising against them vniust matter; taking exception, where no scandall is giuen, to bring them to iust discontent? wherefore (Maister Subdeane) to waste neither more time, nor words about this point; for conclusion (since, as you say, you are come purposely to aske my opinion and counsayle in this matter) my aduise is (if you will be ruled by me) let all matters be husht; rest as they are; and there an end, without either further troubling, or prouoaking him.

Thus the good Doctour soundly, plainely, and, on all parts, charitably afforded him his freindly aduise. And herevpon it was, that Doctour Hutton was satisfied; whereof he gaue sufficient signes, when he receyued the aforesaid copy.

So the matter was, for that time, ended; and the doctrine, without any manner of preiudice, or farther contradiction, cleared: being now at two seuerall tymes by me preached, First generally glanced at, & intimated only: Secondly, against the Brethren (who in priuate corners traduced it) publiquely r • peated, amplified, and explaned.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Hovv, vpon M. Prouicechancellours cessation to prosecute me any farther, D. Benefield in a publick, solemne Lecture, did mainely impugne the aforesaid doctrine; vvith shevv of particular exceptions against me for the same.
div.p:
AND now resolued, as my next occasion drew me to preach, to proceede forwards with the exposition of my text, and to haue vnfolded the sense of the opening of those mysticall bookes; the booke of conscience, and the booke of God his eternall prescience; for so it followed in my text; the bookes vvere opened, and an other booke vvas opened; vvhich is the booke
of lyfe. This was my intention; because I had now spoken sufficiently of that point (as I thought) which I mett withall but obiter in my text, vpon a subdiuision, and a distinction cited foorth of S. Gregory.

As I resolued priuately vpon this course, so I had performed accordingly, if a certaine exorbitant accident had not interrupted, & disturbed this my quiet, and setled resolution; diuerting my purpose (for that present) and conuerting my forces an other way. The occasion wherof was, as followeth.

In the Easter terme following M. Benefield (one of the Inceptors of deuinity for the Act ensuing) whether it were of his owne proper motion (which I very hardly can suppose) or vpon the instigatiō of some other of the BRETHREN (which I do more easily belieue; since he must needes go, whom a maine schisme driueth) purposedly prouided one of his six solemne lectures (read for the assumpt of his degree of Doctourshippe) mainely, and directly by way of opposition, and confutation of that erroneous Popish doctrine. For so it pleased this initiate Doctour to brand the Doctrine of all the Ancient Catholique Doctours,A nevv Doctour of Oxford cōtrary to all the Catholick Doctours of the Church. deliuered concerning EVANGELICALL COVNSAILES. VVherein whether I, and my doctrine were mainely shott at and impugned or no, I will
not iudge in my owne cause; let the equall, and impartiall Reader vmpire for vs both.

This businesse was not so secretly plotted by the aforesaid Brethren, not yet so priuately intended, and caried by the Actor himselfe, but I had certaine notice giuen me by a friend of mine (a graue Bachellour in diuinity,M. R. and a man of good esteme) who was acquainted both with the proiect, and the day of lecture: wherof he gaue me a particular intimation.

This lecture I both heard, and noted in writing. But such an other lecture, so false, so Hereticall, with such violent wresting of sacred write, such impudent reiecting of holy fathers, quite besides the drifte of the one, and cleane contrary to the resolution of the other, I seldome, or neuer heard in that famous, and renowned Academy.

The text by him treated vpon was; go sell all that thou hast, and giue to the poore, and thou shalt haue treasure in heauen; and come, and follovv me. A maine ground, and pregnant text (as I take it; and I take it aright, if all ancient Church mistake it not) to builde vpp rather, then to batter downe; to confirme rather, then to confute Euangelicall Counsailes. The Fathers which he cited, & named to stand for Counsailes were diuers: he might haue vrged all, both of the Greeke, and Latine Church; all of them being
resolute for COVNSAILES (& that vpon those woords of our Sauiour; goe sell all &c. As also vpon that distinctiō of the Apostle; Now concerning virgins I haue no precept from our Lord; but I giue my aduise; or Counsaile) which is a weaghty consideration, if their ioynt consent and vniforme authority might haue borne any sway with this noble Inceptour.

But this nouitiate DOCTOVR (if yet he deserue that title, who dealt thus rudely with the true DOCTOVRS of the Church) as he peruerted the sacred writt of God (his reuealed in will his word) so reiected the FATHERS, blasting them all with this one hereticall breath, that they vvere all bevvitched, deceiued, and caried avvay as men vvith the errours of the time vvherein they lyued. Thus Caluin, Luther, the foure good fellow Germans (who composed their false, & fond Centuries in a stoue of Magdeburge) taught their nouice to blaspheme. O times, ô ages wherein we now liue; when Caluin, Luther, foure carousing Almans (nay rather Ale-men) and one puny doctour, dare thus openly (in the eares of Christendome, & in the publique eye of so famous an vniuersity) blaspheme God his holy spirit, promised by Christ to lodge in the bosome of these venerable, and sober aged Fathers, chiefe pillars of the holy Catholique Church.

And yet after he had thus censoriously handled the FATHERS,This is right the Puritan cutt: as D. Bancroft obserueth against the Presbyterian factiō, in some vvhole, Chapters of his Suruay. vpon my priuate conferēce with him, in stead of the Fathers, which I called for, he offred vnto me two English pamphlets; one wherof was entituled the Apologie of the Church of England; whereat I could not but smile, in regard of his simplicity, though inwardly grieued much at the times misery, when a statizing Pamphleter (who would flye vpon the wing of his penne vnto the height of some ambitious designment) shall be compared, nay preferred before the ancient Orthodox deuines, that painefully laboured in the vineyard of the Church against the brunt of al Heresies.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Hovv the indignity, and leuity of the aforesayd Lecture, prouoked me to addresse a more ample defence of my doctrine.
div.p:
THIS solemne lecture, read in publicke schooles by an Inceptor in deuinity for so venerable a degree, enforced me now (euen as I would not openly betray the truth of this doctrine) vnto a more plaine, ample, and personall defence; inuiting me also, nay inflaming
me with some extraordinary desire, for the reiection, and depulsion of his infirme reasons.

And though diuers of my best frends (whose intreaty in any other matter, might haue preuayled with me) dissuaded me from this enterprise (as being to full of perill) fearing the violence of the time, and the manifould dangers, that by this resolution I stoode likely to expose my selfe vnto, yet ten thousand such like motiues of terrour could not detayne me, nor deterre my resolution. For a higher hand then humane (euen the hand of heauen) so ouerruled me (cōmanding, nay coūtermaunding all my affections that way) that partly the pure zeale, and entire affection (which I euer bare vnto the blessed FATHERS; being wholly indebted vnto them for that little which I haue) and partly my deuoted loue vnto many of that VNIVERSITY; whom I could not patiently suffer to be thus peruerted in so mayne a doctrine, tending to all Religious piety; and lastly the perfit hatred, that from my innermost soule, I euer conceiued against Puritanisme (the very bane of ancient Christianity) these I say, and the like motiues (to recollect them alltogether) could not suffer me, without the shipwracke of all conscience, to sit still and to be silent, whilst God his eternal truth,
Christ his holy direction, & the perpetuall tradition of the Catholick mother-Church were so publickly impugned, and so notoriously prophaned.

1. Reg. 26.Thefore as Abishai, out of his loue to his annointed king, sayd vnto Dauid, when he men • by on blow (surely layd on) to end all quarrells betwixt Saul and him,Benefield, vvithall his comperes. let me strike him but once, yea nayle him to the earth vvith a speare, seing God hath thus closed him into thy hands and I vvill strike him no more; euen so (to apply the words onely; for I iustify not the intended fact of Abishai) my loue vnto the king of heauen (when I purposed by one other blowe soundly giuen, to end this controuersity) forced me to cry within my heart; let me strike him but once and I vvill strike him no more.

And if this blowe haue not hit home to the finall deciding of this quarrell, depriuing his heresy of all breathing, let him, or any, or all his complices (and especially those six well selected doctours, who haue so farre engaged their credits by interessing themselues so deepely in the quarrell) warde, and answere the blow which they haue publickly receiued, for all of them put together haue not yet diuerted the stroke. Or if the cause, which the principal Act or vndertooke,Doctour Benefielde. will abide so much as the least touchstone of tryall, let him, vpon what
grounds, and confidence soeuer he standeth as I dare boldly chardge, and challendg him he stādeth vpon none, but hereticall) diuulge his lecture vnto the sensure of the world.

Meane while, for the honour of God, and confusion of Sathan, to preserue Christ his word (the word of verity) from the infection of Heresy; for the iust defence of this doctrine • the due reproofe of hereticall innouation, • haue thought good here to insert a true copy of the Sermon preached by me in Oxford to iustify EVANGELICALL COVNSAILES vpon the occasion aboue mentioned.anno Domini. 1608. 27. die Iunij.

Reade it (deare Christian brother) seuerly iudge of it impartially; and God graunt it may effect in thee what I wish hartily: and that is (if thou feelest thy selfe called, & thy soule mooued effectually) to practise the same. Amen.

div.head: The sermon preached in defence of Euangelicall Counsayles, and the Fathers.
div.p:
AND I sawe the dead, both great, and sma • stande before God, and the bookes were opened and another booke was opened, Apo • . 20.12. which is the booke of life, and the dead were iudged of those thinges, which were written in the bookes according to their woorks. This verse naturallie floweth i • to three streames, of Christian Doctrine: The fir • is a generall citation of all; and I sawe the dead, bot • great and small stand before God. The second is a particuler examination of all, vppon a twoofould euidence brought in: liber conscientiae, librum praescientia •
the booke of conscience, and the booke of God his aeternall prescience: the bookes were opened, and another booke was opened, which is the booke of life; A finall retribution, inuolued in the acte, and particuler manner of the iudgment; and the deade were iudged of those things, which were written in the bookes accordinge t • their woorkes.

Of the personns appearing, summoned by Christe
his imperiall power commaunding, and produced by Angells voluntarie ministering, and all creatures necessarie obeying, (sea, death, and hell surrendring their dead) I haue already spoken; as also of the extent of this appearaunce; subiection to this throane, and of the Iudge before whome this appearaunce is made.

In the extent of this appearaunce I noted a fourefoulde acception of great and small. FIRSTE great and small for worldlie authoritie, and tēporall condition. SECONDLIE great and small, in respect of heauenlie supereminencie of grace, and spirituall infusion. THIRDLIE great and small, in consideration of diuersitie of rewards, and retribution. FOVRTHLIE great and small, in regard of disparitie, yea contrarietie also of woorkes, and operation.

And from this last signification, arose that fourefoulde distinction of S. Gregorie: 26. lib. in Io • cap. 24.25. quidam non iudicantur, & pereunt; quidam iudicantur, & pereunt; quidam iudicantur, & regnant; quidam non iudicantur, & regnant. That is (as another auncient writer, commentinge vppon my text, fitlie rendereth it) some are not iudged but condemned allreadie; perishing without further iudgment; some are to be iudged, and condemned; perishing by iudgment; some are to be iudged, and saued; saued by iudgment; some are iudged and saued allreadie; saued without iudgment.

The first ranke are suche, whose damnation sleepeth not, but is allreadie certain:Iohn. 3.1 • . Qui non credit in filio Dei IAM iudicatus est; he that beleeueth not in the sonne of God is allreadie condemned, being thereto ordained, and predestinated; ad poenam, non ad culpam;
ad supplicium, non ad peccatum, ad mortem animae, non impietatis primam, sed ad mortem animae, damnationis secundam: as that mellifluous Father Fulgentius speaketh:De predestinatione ad monimum. that is, to penaltie, not to iniquitie; to the wages of sinne, not to the guilte of sinne; not to the first death of the soule, that is transgression, but to the second death of the soule, to wit certaine dānation. For ther sinns (being loude crying sinns) crie with Sodome in the eares of heauen; are open before hande, and goe before them vnto iudgment.

1. Pinn: 5.24.The second sort are suche, whose damnation is yet vncertaine; for admit, that they be nowe in the state of damnation, yet let them turne from ther sinns, God will turne from his wrathe: he offereth them heauen, and threateneth them hell: he setteth life, and death, good and euill, before them: let them reache out their hand, & choose whether they wil.

He that woulde not the deathe of a sinner, (for our mercifull God, would haue all to be saued) offereth meanes of saluation, vnto these sinners; knocking outwardlie, inwardlie, by the operation of his woorde, by the inspiration of his spirit, a • the steepie doore, of ther drousie consciences, to awaken them (if it be possible) from the dead sleepe, and lethargie of sinne: opening their eyes some times, and inlardging their harts, that, if they will, they may come to repentaunce, and amendement of life, out of the snare of the deuill, who are taken of him at his will.

Which meanes of their conuersion, proceeding from his meere compassion (which should leade them to compunction) if they refuse, and after the • hardnes of hart that cannot repent, Rom. 2.6. treasure vppe wrathe against the day of wrathe, then are they taken of sathan
at his will. Hence springeth the secōd braun
• e; some are iudged, and condemned. These happilie, • noughe they haue not sinned with so highe a hand against heauen, as the former haue done; yet certainlie haue they so greiued the spirit, which should haue sealed them vppe vnto the day of redemption, and so highlie haue they offended the Maiestie of heauen, that their sinns followe them vnto iudgment; 1. tim. 5.24. nay dogge them, as a sergeant at heeles, to arreste them.

The third sort are suche, whose saluation is not yet certaine, certitudine rei, thoughe it be spei; not sui, though Dei: with certaintie of reall possessiō, though it be of spirituall expectation; with anie certaintie arising from themselues, but with a certaintie proceeding frō God. Gods promises are conditionall, & his election infalliblie implieth in it, nay poynteth vnto the verie meanes of our saluation; his aeternall prescience so directing the decree of his Counsayle.

These thoughe they stande,1. Cor. 10.12. yet must they take heede lest they fall. For these are but yet in via, not in patria; vppon the seas of this worlde, flotinge, not in the hauen of heauen, raigninge. Beginne they in the spirit? Yet they must not end in the fleshe, Galat. 3.3. or be made perfit by the fl • she. For they are yet in certamine, not in triumpho, warfaring on earthe, encompassed with theiues and pirats, the worlde, fleshe, an deuill on all sides assaultinge them; not triumphinge in heauen, enuironed and garded, with legions of Angells, and armies of the spirits of iust & perfit men.

These must remember, and remembring tremble at that fearfull distriction, and terrible commination (so often reiterated and direfullie threatned by the prophet.) If the righteous turne away from his
righteousnes, and commit iniquitie, and doe according to • the abominations, that the wicked man doth, shall he li • saithe the Lorde God of hoasts? All his righteousnes, that he hath done, shall not be mentioned, but in his transgression, that he hath committed, and in his sinne, that he hath sinned, in them shall he die. And the reason is excellentlie rendred by the Apostle:Heb. 6.4.5.6. For it is impossible, that they which were once enlightened, and haue tasted of the heauenlie guifte, and were made partakers of the holie ghoaste, and haue tasted of the good woorde of God, and of the powers of the worlde to come, if they fall awaye, should be renewed by repentance, seing they crucifie againe to them selues the sonne of God and make a mocke of him.

I speake not this (my Brethren) to shake the certaintie, of anie soules saluation, rightlie builte on gods election, but to giue a caueat to all (a caueat indeede, and a terrible one too) to dehort vs from all sinfull secure presumption of heauen, lest from the steepe pitche of an ouerweening securitie, and presuming certaintie, we tumble headlonge downe into hell, as also a motiue, to exhort, and stirre vs vppe all, to make our callinge, and el • ction sure by woorking out our saluation with feare, and tremblinge. For continuance, and perseueraunce onlie sealeth vnto vs the assuraunce of our saluation, since truthe that cannot lye, nor deceaue, hath plainlie taught vs; he that continueth vnto the end he shalbe saued.

The last sort are suche, whose saluation is already certain; and these differ from the other, quoad gradū; gradum in via, perfectionis; gradum in patria, retributionis. For if stella a stella differt gloria (the Apostle applieth it to the bodilie resurrection) that is,2. Cor. 15.41. if ther be degrees of exaltation in the kingdome of glorie; of necessitie, by force of ineuitable consequence, it
must followe, that there be degrees of Christian perfection in the kingdome of grace, the one being a retribution of the other; heauens remuneration awarded, accordinge to Christian perfection practised.

These ioyne with their faithe, vertue, 2. pet. 1.5.6.7.10. with vertue knowledge, with knowledge temperaunce; with temperaunce patience, with patience, godlines; with godlines, brotherlie kindnes; with brotherlie kindnes, loue; the verie bonde of perfection, nay plíroma tou nomou; the fulfillinge of the lawe; and doing these things they can neuer fall. These giue all diligence to make their callinge, and election sure by faithe, by woorkes, by precepts, by Counsailes. These are terrestres Angeli, coelestes homines, earthlie Angells, heauenlie men: • heir names are written in heauen, and them selues registred, and enrolled, in the booke of life, and of • he lambe. These (I remember well) I stiled entiae • anscendentia, men soaring with the wings of faithe and woorkes, aboue the ordinarie pitche of men:
• iam praecepta legis perfectiori virtute transcendentes; tran
• cending, surmountinge the precepts of the lawe, by Euangelicall Counsailes of greater perfection: so speaketh S. Gregorie in the place aboue cited.

For explanation of which sentence of that good Father, and great pillar of the Latine Churche wee are to note, that precepts and Counsailes, may be considered comparatiuelie two manner of wayes; viz. either GENERALLIE, comparing all the precepts of the lawe ioyntlie with the Counsailes of the gospell seuerallie, or PARTICVLARLY, by comparing seuerall Counsailes of the gospell, not with euerie, or with all the precepts of the lawe ioyntly in one aggregate bodie, but seuerallie with
the precepts conuersant circa eandem materiam.

Ps • l. 119.In the first consideration, I stand not to iustifie those woords of S. Gregorie, transcendunt aliqui praecept • legis perfectiori virtute. For mandatum tuum nimis latu • Domine: thy commaundement, ô Lorde, is exceding • broad: yea so broad, that the lawe alone, lex immaculata, that vndefiled lawe of God, containeth in it, prima • ilie, originallie, essentiallie, all kinde of Christian perfection; and it was neuer that orthodoxe Fathers meaninge so to compare them. But in the later consideration, most true are those woordes of S. Gregorie; transcendunt aliqui praecepta legis perfection virtute.

To illustrate this comparison by example. FIRST compare that Euangelicall Counsaile, vade, vend • omnia, & da pauperibus, & sequere me, with that precept, non furaberis: And SECONDLIE cōpare tha • Euangelicall Counsaile of virginitie,Math: 19.11. qui potest caper • capiat. (Which Luther himselfe in the 30. artic. of his assertion held to be the onlie Euāgelicall Counsaile) with that precept, non moechaberis: then you shall see euidently, that an higher degree of perfection is in the action cōformable to those twoo Counsailes, the • in the actions inioyned in the other two Precepts. Fo • in actions there must needes be degrees of goodnes witnesse some actions good in a meane degree of goodnes; as not to hate his owne fleshe, to require good for good, not to steale, not to cōmitte adulterie, &c. Wherein I may demaund with our Sauiour what singular thinge is done? doe not publicans do the same? Did not blind foulded gentilisme do these things? Other actions there are, which are good in a higher degree of goodnes: such are the actions perfourmed in the Counsailes of voluntarie pouertie,
virginitie, and the like.

All perfection of man here, as it is in the waye of perfection to the seruice of God, is not equall, witnesse the Apostles forsaking all, and followinge Christe: did all do so that beleiued in Christe? Witnesse the first feruour, and zeale, of the primitiue Churche (newly founded, in the bloud of Christe, and watered in the bloud of his Apostles) selling all their possessions, without the least reseruatiō of any parte, and layinge downe the whole price therof at the Apostles feete; witnesse. S. Augustine in his 18.Cap. 11. sermon de verbis Apostoli: where that good Father speaketh thus in the person of certain virgins (in his time) religiouslie deuoted, and consecrated vnto the entire seruice of their God. Quod iubes, ne adulterae simus, hoc praecipis: amando te plus facimus quàm iubes. Wheras thou commaundest vs not to cōmitt adulterie, this thou giuest vs in chardge by waye of precept; but in louing thee, wee doe more then thou cōmaundest. Witnesse learned,He meaneth in this peculiar kind. and iudicious Hooker in the second booke of his Churche Politie, in the thirde page before the ende of the same booke: Witnesse also the Apologie in defence of him, written by Doctor Couell; in the fourten the chapter; of satisfaction.

The perfection of man here in this life, is the soules vnion with God; not essentiall, (for this is peculiar onely to the Trinitie.) Not personall (this proper to Christe his humanitie.) Not sacramentall (this extendeth to the whole Churche in generall.) But it is, vnio animae spiritualis, Ber. in psal. 23. the soules spirituall vnion with God, when the soule is wholly sequestred from the worlde, and is syncerelie rauished with the loue of God, of Christe,
and of her neighbour; guided, and ledde ther vnto by precepts, and Counsailes.

Which precepts, and Counsailes, thoughe they perfourme this, yet doe they diuerslie direct therevnto, according to the diuersitie of those things, about which they are conuersaunt; differinge onlie in modo, and not in re.

To explaine this point. Some things are cōtrarie to the loue of God, wherwith Charitie, and the loue of God, can haue no more agreement, then light & darknes, God and Beliall, the Arke and Dagon, Baal his false preists, and Eliah the lordes true Prophet. And for remoouing these forthe of the waye of perfection, precepts are mainely giuen.

Ber. ser. 35. 36. paruorum sermonum.Other things are impedimenta charitatis, or impedimenta actus charitatis: that is, non illicita, sed impedimenta iustitiae; impediments of charitie, or impediments of the acts of charitie, to witt not things simplie vnlawfull, but encombraunces vnto righteousnes: & for remoouing of these lettes, COVNSAILES are giuen.

The first inioyneth abstinence from things simplie euill, & vnlawfull, that cannot stande with the loue of God, nay contrarie to the loue of God, and of our neighbour. And for remoouing of these, a • PRECEPT is necessarie. The seconde commaundeth not, but aduiseth abstinence, from things not simplie euill, nor in them selues vnlawfull; as marriage, and the riches of this worlde (the good creatures of God) but they may well stand with the loue of God; yet may they be so vsed, nay rather abused, that they may withdraw the minde from the loue of God.
• . Cor. 7.33. Qui duxit vxorem, curat quae sunt mundi: the married man careth for the things, that
are of this worlde, &c. Again; it is easier for a camell to passe throughe the eye of a needle, then for a riche man, that trusteth in his riches, (for so Christe expoundeth it) to enter into the kingdome of heauen. Are not here marriage, and the consequences therof (necessarilie insuinge) riches, and the cares therof, impedimenta iustitiae, letts, and encombraunces vnto righteousnes? And therfore these are left arbitrarie, and at our free choice, to be followed, or pretermitted, as euerie mans proper guift shalbe;2. Cor. 7.7. vnusquisque suum habet donum; euerie man hath his proper guifte. So S. Hierom ad Eustochium; and against Iouinian, S. Ambrose, in the 10. booke of his Epistles; the 82. Epistle ad Vercellensem Ecclesiam; and in his tract de viduis, towards the ende. S. Augustine in his 61. sermon de tempore: the second booke of his Euangelicall questions, chapter the 19. and in his Enchiridion, ad Laurentium chapter the 121.

Precepts and Counsailes therefore differ thus. PRECEPTS are of necessitie; COVNSAILES arbitrarie, left to our free choice. Bothe ayme at the marke of heauē, by shootinge at the butte of Christian perfection, but differ in the manner. Both leuell at the meanes of saluation: that is, perfection of charitie, yet Counsailes after a more exquisite, and excellinge perfection.

The stage of this worlde, and the theater of the Churche present vnto our free choice the worlds trashe, and heauens true treasure, the more man cleaueth to heauens permanent felicitie, the more perfit, and excellent is he; nay to cast the worlds trashe wholly awaie in lue of heauens treasure, as seafaring men doe their goods and wares, in daunger of shipwracke, when the life is in hazarde, this
is no precepte of necessitie, but onlie an aduise of greater perfection.
Transgressors of the lawes precepts, deserue punnishment; but they that perfourme not Counsailes sinne not; only they wāt some measure of perfectiō.

Obseruers of Counsailes shall haue greater reward, yea they shall sit vppon throanes; & not onlie iudge the twelue tribes of Israell, but doome both men & Angells. It was Christ his promise of remuneration made to his disciples for their consolation, to encourage them to goe forwards with the practise of Christian perfection, embracing for his, & heauens sake, voluntarie pouertie, virginall chastitie, and humble obedience. It was proclaymed also by that trumpet of the Apostles, preacher of the worlde, Apostle of the Gentiles, and descrier of heauenly mysteries, holie, and blessed S. Paul; knowe you not, that wee shall iudge the Angells? &c. The woordes are so pregnant, that all the wrangling witts, and contentious priuate spirits in the worlde cannot wrest them. But lawe breakers, without repētaunce, shall haue greater punishment.

To shutte vppe all in one woorde; Precepts are exalted as necessary; Counsailes are offred as voluntarie, and arbitrarie. The one being done, is praysed, and highlie rewarded: the other being vndone, is reprehended, and punnished.

This distinction betwixt precepts, and Counsailes, is no new Doctrine. S. Hierom ad Eustochium, de custodia virginitatis, and against Iouinian, layeth downe the pointe, and difference thus. VVhere there is a COVNSAILE, there is left a freedome; but PRECEPTS inioyne a necessitie; precepts are common to all, Counsailes are the perfection of some fewe. (And this is agreeinge
with that of Gregorie in the place aboue cited; non omnibus praecipiuntur, sed perfectioribus consuluntur: they are not commaunded to all, but aduised to men of the perfiter ranke.) Precepts obserued haue a rewarde, not obserued a punnishment; Counsailes not obserued haue no punnishment, but obserued haue a greater rewarde.

And to this purpose, almost in the verie selfe same woords speaketh S. AVGVSTINE in his 61. sermon de tempore: his 18. sermon de verbis Apostoli: his second booke of Euangelicall questions cap. 19. and in his Enchiridion ad Laurentium cap. 12. S. AMBROSE in the 10. booke of his Epistles, the 82. Epistle ad Vercellensem Ecclesiam; and his tract de viduis, propè finem: and generally the Greeke and Latine Fathers: such is the vniforme consent, and heauenlie harmonie of all orthodoxe Antiquitie in this point of Doctrine.

The defence therfore of Euangelicall Counsailes of perfectiō quoad viam, & quoad gradum, which I would onlie commende vnto the learned & iudicious (who well knowe that the whole course of Antiquitie, & concurrence of the fathers do often mention them) is this; that there are in the gospell of Christe certaine COVNSAILES, which the Auncient pillers, & Patriarches of diuinitie, call CONSILIA PERFECTIONIS Counsailes of perfection: and they are so called, non quòd ipsae sint perfectiones, sed dispositiones quaedā ad perfectionem, quae cōstat in hoc, vt mens hominis Deo vacet: that is, not that they are in themselues perfections indeede, but rather dispositions, directions, preparations to perfection, which consisteth mainelie in this; that the soule (wholly sequestred from the worlde) may be trulie, and sincerely rauished with the loue of God, and of hi • neighbour.

And therefore as Origen excellentlie obserueth in his commentarie vppon S. Mathewe his 8. Homilie, vppon those woords of our Sauiour, giuen by waye of Counsaile to the youngmanne: if thou wilt be perfit, &c. Non sic debemus intelligere, vt in eo ipso tempore, quo homo dat bona sua pauperibus, efficiatur omnino perfectus, sed incipit ex eo tempore speculatio Dei adducere eum ad omnes virtutes, vt incipiat ex eo tempore proficere: that is to say; we are not so to vnderstand perfection, that in the verie moment, wherein a man giueth all his goods to the poore, he is made altogether perfitt, but from that time forwards, the speculatiō of God beginneth to leade him vnto all vertues, that euer after he maketh a good progresse.

This also is euident in the wordes of our Sauiour, where he placeth not perfection in ipsa diuitiarum abdicatione, in the verie renouncing of riches, but rather teacheth, that the forsaking of the worlde is a certaine direction, preparation, or disposition vnto perfection. And so the verie forme, and manner of Christ his speache doth euidentlie conuince. For first he proposeth the question to his arbitrarie election: If thou wilt be perfit. Secondly, he pursueth it with a direction: goe sell all that thou hast, and giue to the poore. Thirdly, he inferreth the conclusion, the verie life, and consummation of perfection; followe me. Lastlie he annexeth the remuneratiō, the forciblest motiue that possible coulde be to drawe a man to that resolution of Christian perfection; thesaurum habebis in coelo, thou shalt not want thy rewarde.

Now this followinge of Christe (which is nothinge els but the soules spirituall vnion with God) is our Christian perfection: wherevnto the abdication of riches fitteth, and prepareth a man, listening
not so muche to that which is lawfull, as to that which is expedient: auoydinge riches, and other things of like nature, not as things vnlawfull, but as impediments, and hinderances vnto righteousnes.

And S. Augustine, in his Enchiridion ad Laurentium, Cap. 121. is of opinion, that perfection of charitie (which is the perfection of Christian life) consisteth neither in the sole performaunce of the actions of precepts, conformable to non moechaberis: nor yet in the perfourmance of the actions of Counsailes, vnlesse both actions of precepts, and Counsayles, be rightlie referred with relatiō to the ende, of all the actions of precepts and Counsailes, which is charitas erga Deum, & proximum propter Deum: charitie toward God primarily, and charitie towards our neighbour for gods sake, secondarily.

And because the performance of the actions of precepts, are, in themselues, absolutely necessarie for atcheiuing this ende (being suche, as without it, the ende cannot be attayned) and the performance of the other of Counsailes doth onlie secondarily tende thervnro, as a helpe, or as a remouens impedimentum: hence is it that schoole-diuines, haue this distinction, or rather conclusion comprised in a distinction: viz. Perfection of charitie, which is the perfection of Christian life, consisteth PRIMARIO, ET ESSENTIALITER IN PRECEPTIS; but SECVNDARIO, ET ACCIDENTALITER IN CONSILIIS; primarily, and essentially in precepts; but seeondarily, and accidentally in Counsayles.

If anie be so wedded to his owne priuate humour, as not, in this sense,Benefield, & his confederates in Iouinians heresy. to admit of Euangelicall Counsailes of perfection, quoad viam, and quoad
gradum, but that they will confounde Precepts, and Counsailes together (houlding both of like necessitie, Counsailes aswell as precepts) so did the heretiques called Apostolici: August. haeres: 40. Epiphane haeres 61. or that Counsailes containe in them no kinde of perfection; it is a braunche of Iouinian, & Vigilantius their cōdemned heresie. Reade S. Hierom against Iouinian; and S. Ambrose in the 10. booke of his Epistles, the 80. and 81. Epistles. Or lastlie, if any will hold the profession of them vnlawfull, & that there be none; the first crosseth many pregnant testimonies of scriptures veritie; and the secōd thwarteth the ioynt consent of al orthodoxe Antiquitie. The which Tertullian de praescriptionibus aduersus haereticos; Cyprian de vnitate Ecclesiae: Augustine de vtilitate credendi; Vincentius Lyrinensis in his Commonitorium against all the prophane innouation of heretiques of his time, make to be the verie square of propheticall, & Apostolicall interpretation, drawne a longe by the line of the Churche.

Principally Benefild.And therefore first; I would but aske them, what our blessed Sauiour meant, Matth the 19. (who vppon occasion of the diuorce, his disciples perplexed, the difficultie of chastitie, exemplified by Eunuches so borne, so made, so making themselues; à natura; à violentia; à voluntate, naturallie, violentlie, voluntarilie; as Aquinas well obserueth vppon the place) I say, what meant our Sauiour to propose, qui potest capere, capiat, if ther be no COVNSAILE of virginity? Secondly; I would demaund; what Christ meant, Matthew the 19. to aduise the younge man (and that in a matter of the greatest moment; euen the saluation of his soule) goe sell all that thou hast, and giue to the poore, and thou shalt haue treasure in heauen, &c. If
here be not a Counsaile of voluntarie pouertie? For as trulie as Christ meant to performe his promise in the remuneration, thesaurum habebis in coelo; so was it vppon condition, that the younge man should embrace that Counsaile of voluntarie pouertie, tending to the toppe of Christian perfection.

Did Christe, in this, discouer the younge manne his hypocrisie? Some interpreters say so:Caluin. Marke. 10.22. but S. Marke saith no. For Christe looked vppon him, and he loued him. It was not (I hope) for his hypocriticall profession and vaine ostentation; but for some good performance, disposition, and inclination. Agayn; Christ had erroneouslie taught him the way to life, by vade, & vende omnia, and that this was that one thinge necessarie to aspire to the toppe of Christian perfection, if here be not a Counsaile of voluntary pouertie. And this is no lesse then open blasphemie against the Maiestie of heauen.Caluin is a blasphemous interpreter.

Lastlie I would but demaund, what S. Paul meant 2. Cor. 7.25. to distinguish plainelie betwixt Precepts and Counsailes, thus; praeceptum non habeo, vid. Damasc. dict Gnomi in Indice. consilium do (for so the vulgar readeth; which all the latine • hurche followeth: and all the greeke fathers • aue soe taken it) if there be no Counsailes? For he groundeth this his distinction vppon his Maisters wordes; Non omnes capiunt, and therfore S. Paul had noe precept. But qui potest capere, capiat. And hence floweth the secōd branch; consilium do: as S. Hierom, S. Basill, & diuers others of both Churches do obserue.

And that this point may be euerie way full, and perfit, builded vppon so manie seuerall rockes, as there be seuerall places of Scriptures:Vincentius Lyrin. in cō • monitorio. let the Doctors of the Churche speake, being the most probable
Maisters & teachers in the Church: &, against quot capita, tot sensus (the verie bane of all religion and mother of innouation) let the Churche interpret Scripture; and he that will not heare the Churche, you knowe what followeth; sit tibi tanquam hereticus? Nay; sit tibi tanquam ethnicus. For as it is saide of the letter of the scripture, that it is not of anie priuate inspiration (For it came not in ould time, 2. Peter. 1. vlt. by the will of man, but holie men spake as they were moued by the holie ghost.) So may it be as trulie saide of the sense of the Scripture, that it is not of anie priuate spiritts interpretation. And the reason, why euerie man should fly from a priuate spirits interpretation, is this (as it is excellentlie rendred by that mellifluous Father,Serm. 17. in Cantic. S. Bernard) Nonnulli adesse putant spiritum, cùm non adest, suúmque sensum pro sensu spiritus sequuntur deuiantes, suásque sententias magistrorum sententijs praeferunt; A sentence that striketh the Religion in England as dead, as a doore nayle that is (for I cannot but translate it) manie men thinke that they haue the Spirit of God, when they haue it not: erroneouslie followinge the sense of their owne priuate spirits for the meaninge of the holie Ghost: preferring their owne priuate opinions before the publique iudgmentes of ther maisters, and teachers.

It is lawfull to follow the spirit in interpretinge the scripture: but it must be the spirit of the Church: that spirit of peace, vnitie, charitie, that descended vppon the Apostles vnited, for domus vna, &c. they abode all in one house; a signe of externall charitie; Mens, & anima vna; one minde, one soule; for they had but one God, one faithe, one Churche; a signe of internall,Ancient Church. Caluins, and Luthers congregations. spirituall vnitie. The same spirit euer since continued in the Churche, vnited in faithe, not diuided in faction. And wee may
seeke for the sense of the scripture: but where? It must not be out of the stinkinge puddle of a priuate braine;The aforesayd gentlemen, &c. but forthe of the treasuring memorie of the Churche. Christi Euangelio vim non inferat humana praesumptio: patrum semel definita non sunt iterum in dubium vocanda: This is contrary to cursed Luther. it is blessed Leo in his 94. Epistle: let not humane presumption dare to offer violence vnto the gospell of Christe: for the constitutions of fathers, once decreed, are not further to be questioned. Nec definitiones eorum perpetuae commutandae, quorum regulam secundum scripturam esse didicimus. (So speaketh Flauianus bishoppe of Constantinople in his Epistle to Pope LEO the firste) Neither are the perpetuall determinations of them to be chaunged, whose rule wee haue learned to agree with scripture.

And therfore to exemplifie further vppon this grounde, and to raise the particuler building vppon this generall foundation: I would but aske; what meant S. Cyprian (that auncient famous martyr, in his tract de Natiuitate Christi. sectione 10 penultima) and S. Gregorie (that woorthy pillar of the latine Churche) in his 26. booke on Iob to stile these consilia pe • fectionis, Counsailes of perfection, if there be no Counsailes? Secondly; what meant Theodoret. Primasius, Sedulius, Haymo, Theophylact, Ambrose, Augustine, Hierome, Gregorie, Basill, Chrysostome, Beda, Lyra, Aquinas, Anselmus, with all antiquitie greeke and latine Churche, so to expounde that place of S. Paul 1. Cor. 7.25.

Thirdlie; what meant S. Hierome ad Eustochium, and against that Epicurean Heretique Iouinian (one of the first impugners of this Doctrine) S. Ambrose in the tenth booke of his Epistles, the 82. ad Vercellensem
Ecclesiam, and in his tract de viduis propè finem: S. Augustine in his 61. sermon de tempore, his 18. tracte de verbis Apostoli, chapter the 21. his 2. booke of Euangelicall questions, chapter the 19. and in his Enchiridion ad Laurentium, chapter 121. Origen vppon the 15. to the Rom. S. Basill de vera virginitate: S. Chrysostome in his 8. Homilie de poenitentia: Nazianzen in his 3. oration (which is the first inuectiue against Iulian) and many others? The time would faile me, if I should reckon vppe all. And therfore to close vppe all in a word; What meant all antiquitie, greeke, and latine fathers, so to distinguishe betwixt precepts, and Counsailes, if ther be no Counsailes.

To theis I might add Wickliffe against the order of begging friers: where he stileth them Christ hi • highe COVNSAYLES. Likewise Luther in the 30. article of his assertions. Iudicious & learned Hooke •
in his Churche Politie, and the Apologie in defence of him in the chapter of satisfaction. The Bishoppe of Rochester (and elect of Lincolne) in his sermon preached at court cōcerning the authoritie of Bishopps;D. Barlovv. the 4. page, before the ende.

These, and manie more of their ranke I might adde; if I could be persuaded, that the Fathers needed their sonns suffrages.Sonnes in this poynt; or such like. For no othervvayes did I meane. And yet certaine I am, that the sonns stande in neede of their fathers testimonies. Or were it not rather so, that all these (being men of eminent note in our Churche) are rather relatores antiquae fidei, quàm authores nouae doctrinae; relators of the auncient faithe of the Churche, (to their credit and honour, in that respect, be it spoken) rather then authours, & coyners of anie newe doctrine? And therfore passing them, and for this time sparing them, not to strike a hairs breadth
from my former grounds; my maine conclusion is this: maneant termini patrum, Leo Epist. 17. & 94. intráque fines proprios se quisque contineat: sufficiant limites, quos sanctorum patrum prouidentissima decreta posuerunt: let the bounds of auncient Churche abide, and let euerie man keepe himselfe within due bounds, and limits; let the meetes which the Fathers most prouident decrees haue set, content vs. And the reason is excellentlie rendred by S. Bernard: Epist. 77. ad Hugonē de S. Victore. viz. quantò viciniores erant ad
• entui saluatoris, tantò mysterium salutis pleniùs p •• ecepe
• unt: the nearer the Fathers were to Christ his incarnation, the more clearlie, and fullie receaued they the mysterie of saluation.

To these, were my iudgment and opinion any, I durst not otherwayes then subscribe with all humble submission to the censure of the Churche; • earinge that censure of Flauianus (Bishoppe of Con
• tantinople,) in his first Epistle to Pope Leo the first;Of Luther, Caluin, and all their proper disciples Qui nō consentit Sāctorum Patrum expositionibus, seipsum alienat ab omni sacerdotali communione, & à Christi praesertia Eudoxius in Cōcil. Chalced. Haeretici est praecepta patrum declinare, & instituta eorum • espicere: It is the propertie of an Heretique to de
• line the precepts of holie fathers, contemninge • her cannons, and decrees.

Thus much be spoaken in defence of that great pillar of the latine Churche S. Gregorie saying; Quidam non iudicantur, & pereunt, quidam iudicantur, & pereunt; quidam iudicantur, & regnant, quidam non iudicantur, & regnant: as also in defence of that sentence, inferred vppon the last braunche, transcen
• unt aliqui praecepta legis perfectiori virtute.

This I haue the rather done (God, and his holie Angells in whose presence I nowe stande, and • peake, bearinge me witnesse) lest that imputation • f Fulgentius should light vppon me;De Mysterio Mediatoris lib. 1. viz. Fidem • cclesiae nolle asserere, est negare, vno eodémque silentio
firma errorem, As hereticks as tempori
• ers. qui errore, seu tempore possessus, veritatem silendo non astruit; Dominicam gloriam qui non firmârit, euacuat; & diuinam contumeliam qui non refutarit, accumulat. Miles ignauus somnolento corpore depressus, regia castra oppugnantibus tradit, dum competentibus vigilijs non defendit. That is; not to auerre the Doctrine of the Churche, is to denie the faithe of the Churche; for with one, and the selfe same silence, he streingtheneth an errour,So are some in England. So are others, who being possessed or carried awaye with errour, or time, auoucheth not truthe by his silence. He that confirmeth not the glorie of God, weakneth it; and he that confuteth not iniurie offred vnto God, augmenteth it. The slothfull sleepie souldier betrayeth the Kings tents to his enimies, whilst he keepeth not true sentinell as he shoulde.

Hath anie weedes of superstitiō growne vpp with this Doctrine in the feilde of the Churche? Oh le • not the pure wheate of Euangelicall Counsailes of perfection quoad viam, quoad gradum, fare the wors • for the weedes. Vnskilfull husbandmen are they & verie vnfit to manure, the Lord his tillage, whose preposterous zeale issuing from the grounde of • priuate groundles iudgment, would pull vppe bot • wheate, and tares together.

These are wiser, and fuller of zeale, then Christ • himself, who suffred, nay gaue commaundement (a • it is in the parable) that both tares and wheate shoul • growe together, vntill the haruest of the last iudgment; and then should the tares, and weedes b • bounde vppe in bundles, fitted for the fire; and the wheate should be gathered in to his barne. For a • the last iudgment,sermo. 3. de Ieiunio & collectis. ther are somethings vrenda flammis, other things condenda horreis, as S. LEO speaketh
And doth not S. Paul allude to this?1. Cor. 3.12.23. Whose woordes be; if anie man builde vppon Christ (the foundation) gould, siluer, pretious stones, timber, haye, stubble; euery mans woorke shalbe made manifest, for the day shall declare it, because it shalbe reuealed by the fire, and the • re shall trie euerie mans woorkes, of what sorte they are. To which fire, let this Doctrine be reserued to stand, or fall; to burne as stubble, hay, timber; or rather to escape, as goulde, siluer, and pretious stones.
Now to God onlie wise be rendred prayse, power, might, maiestie, rule, dominion, and thanksgiuinge, and let all the creatures in heauen, • n earthe, or vnder the earthe, say so be it; Amen.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. A Conclusion of the FIRST PART; vvith an admonition vnto the Academicall Reader.
div.p:
THVS (gentle Reader) thou hast seene my mayne defence of this doctrine, wherein I haue followed the mature aduise of the Philosopher, and Oratour.Arist. in Topicis Cicero ad Heren. For I thought it not sufficient to confirme truth in the former part of this sermon, vnlesse I confuted falsehood also in the later. And this I did for establishing thee
if thou be in the right: or reducing thee vnto it, if thou hast bene in the wronge.
