And howsoeuer the truth of this doctrine hath not allready (nor yet haply herafter shall) escape the tongues, and penns of some malitious, or ignorant carping aduersaries) enimies of God, and his Church) yet can it neuer be suppressed; but it will preuayle in the end, and florish like a greene palmetree; being iustifiable and glorious both before God, & man where reason swayeth, and not passion rageth.

Farther; I can for more full complement (if neede be) produce all charters, roles, euidences, iudgments, censures, sentences, arrests of all Christian parliaments, the vmpiring determinations of the highest Ecclesiasticall tribunalls, & generall Councells notwithstanding all pretenses, pleas, intrusions, surreptions, shifts, cōtentions of all Hereticall Iouinianists.

Such is the difference betwixt truth, and falsehood, that errour in time (as it is but the enterteynement of time) will of it selfe fall away,Ad nihillum • leuenient tanquā aqua decurrens: vvhich S. Augustine doth f •• ly apply • nto heresies when TRVTH will stand impregnable, how many soeuer impugne her; so true is that of the Apostle; vve can do nothing against truth.

And therfore leauing thee (modest, and discrete Reader) to iudge of the matter, and doctrine now in difference, as reason, and Religion shall induce thee, and not as the instigation
& humour of some factious persons will seeke to misleade thee; I proceede to prosecute the remaynder of this businesse; hoping that no man (of any apprehension) will suffer him selfe to be deceaued by vaine, and vnlearned suggestions.

And if some men will obstinately shutt their eyes, yet my trust is, that others will looke vp to Heauen, whence this doctrine descended, and whither it doth most readily conduce; & • hat they will no longer take darkenesse for light, night for day, poyson for medecine, Heresy for verity; since truth bringeth euer with it, certainty, peace, & security at the last.

argument.p: THE SECOND PART Contayning the irregular, & violent processe of the Vicechancellour, & hi • complices against me, and the former doctrine. Ʋvherein the Reader may excellently discerne the nature of heresy, and the condition of Hereticks, as in a perfitt glasse.

epigraph.q: As Iannes, and Mambres resisted Moses, so do theis resist the truth; men corrupt in mynd, & reprobate concerning the faith. 2. Tim. 3.8.

div.head: A TRIVMPH OF TRVTH. OR DECLARATION OF THE DOCTRINE CONCERNING EVANGELICALL COVNSAYLES;
CHAP. I. Hovv D. HVTTON conuented me vpon the deliuery of the last Sermon; and vvhat occurrents passed at that time.
div.p: WHEN I had ended my sermon, it seemed good vnto M. Doctour Hutton (who was there present, and confronted me with ridiculous behauiour) to cite me before him selfe immediately in his owne lodging; where I found him accompanied with two other Doctours; D. Kilby, and D. Benefield, who gaue speciall attention vnto my sermon, with great shew of discontent.

Before these men, D. Hutton beganne to chardge me with scandalous, erroneous, and Popish doctrine, fitter to be preached in Rome, then in Oxford; and therefore, in no case to be suffred there to disturbe the peace of the vniuersity.

To this accusation, I framed my answeare to the same tenour, and effect, as you haue formerly seene in the kitchin-conference; adding farther, that the doctrine of the Trinity, consubstantiality &c. might be branded with the imputation of POPERY, aswell as this doctrine of EVANGELICALL COVNSAILES.

But such is the temerity of some men, that they will rather disclayme a manifest truthe, then they will concurre in opinion with the Church of Rome. And for my part, I see no reason, why you may not aswell renounce that Popish doctrine of the Trinity, as this of Euangelicall Counsayles, since both haue their euidence from the same ground (Canonicall Scripture and Ecclesiasticall Tradition) yea the later hath more cleare deduction, and testification out of the Scripture then the former.

Secondly; his worshippe obiected vnto me that D. Benefield had lately; and learnedly confuted the said Popish doctrine of Euangelicall Counsayles, and that therevpon I ought to haue surceased; my reply was, that D. Benefield his
opinion was no canon of my faith, nor that his authority was of such value with me, as to preponderate the iudgment of the Ancient Church, & testimonies of the venerable Fathers. And therefore since I beganne to publishe this doctrine vppon such groundes, I was bound in conscience to defend the same; and specially, since he made an opposition in schooles vnto my position in the pulpit; so that I could not be silent without treason vnto God, and his truth.

Thirdly; whereas he laid vnto my chardge, that he had inhibited me to intermeddle any farther with this point; I answered; rhat de facto, he had neuer done it, and that, de iure, he could not do it. For God must be obayed rather then man. Besides; though in discretion,Act. 5. and submissiō vnto your authoritie, I would haue surceased from prosecution of this matter, yet this notorious, & intollerable impugnatiō did force me to breake my intended silence.

Fourthly; whereas he demaunded a copy of my sermon (protesting vpon his faith, & troth to God, that he would send me presently vnto the Castle, vnlesse I then deliuered it) I was content (vpon the perswasion of D. Kilbye) to yealde into his handes the original, and onely copy therof. And so I was dismissed for this time.

div.head: CHAP. II. Hovv the Vicechancellour, after his returne from London, intreated me in his lodging.
div.p: THIS storme being thus ouerblowne, a quiet calme ensued, vntill M. Doctour King (deane of Christ-Church, and Vicechancellour of the vniuersity) was now returned from London; vnto whom I made repayre, partly to do my duty vnto him, & partly to preuent that sinister impression, which D. Hutton, & others sought to worke in him to the preiudice of me and of the doctrine which I had preached. For which purpose, I had collected the testimonies of 24. Fathers; that therby he might be well informed in the state of this present question.

As soone as he beheld me, he brake foorth into this passionate declamation. Sir, would you haue a vvord vvith me? In very good time; I haue many vvords to speake with you: for the shameful rumour of your doctrine hath filled my eares wheresoeuer I came, in London, in Lambeth, or else where: your doctrine was still laid in my dish; yea I haue bene chardged by diuers to my face, for tolerating such scandalous, and erroneous doctrine freely, and openly to be preached in this vniuersity.

To whom returning my answere in dutifull
sort, I protested first, that I came not to insinuate with him, nor to diuert any course of iustice. Secōdly; I know the doctrine to be founded vpon such inuincible proofes, & reasons, that it will stād impregnable against al assaults whatsoeuer. For demonstration wherof I presented the aforesaid testimonies vnto him, and desired him to take a diligent reuiew of the places alleaged in that schedule.

Vvherevpon he contēptuously entwited me, saying: go, go; you are a foole, an asse &c. vvhen you preach, here is nothing but Leo, Leech, and all the Fathers. A prouerbe, which he had borrowed frō some braynsick Puritans, & prophane scoffers.
VVhich contumely I repelled with few words, and digested it with patience; assuring him, that Leech with one LEO would be too hard for any man that impugned this doctrine.

And truly I could not but maruaile, that he, who in his lectures vpon Ionah, hath made a copious defence of the holy Fathers, and approueth the vse of their testimonies in publique sermōs, should now so vehemently except against me, and so meanely esteeme of them. But such is the condition of these men, that they will accept, and reiect the Fathers at their owne pleasures; as winde, and weather go.

Now, whereas I added farther, that the best learned in Oxford concurred with me in this
point; yea (said he) there are many of you, that vvill play vvith POPERY, as the flye doth vvith the candle: you hoouer, ouer and about it, as neere as you dare, but you vvill be sure to keepe your vvinges from sindging.

Though I made a freindly defence of those men (at whom he malitiously gyrded) as being men of incomparable worth in that place, yet I disclaymed al assistance from them, or any others, protesting, that I depended not vpon men, nor Angells; but only vpon the sacred Scripture, interpreted by the ancient Church. VVhich rule of faith as it is most certaine, so my application therof, in this particular, is free from all exception.

VVell (quoth he) vvhether I shall be able to prooue this doctrine, false, or not, I can not tell: but, as I thinke, I shall. Hovvsoeuer; certaine I am, that I shall be able to condemne you of great indiscretion, for preaching such doctrine in these reuolting times, vvhen there is such generall Apostasy from the gospell vnto POPERY.

At which simple suggestion I could not but smile within my selfe; first to consider, that whereas he had absolutely charged this doctrine to be erroneous, yet now he could not tell whether it were true, or false. Secondly, to obserue, that the preaching of truth, contayned in the gospell, should be a meanes to draw
men from the gospell vnto Popery; as he was pleased to speake.

But perceiuing him to be enkindled with the flames of passion, I forboare to adde fuel vnto the fire; and therefore I pretermitted the mentioning of his follies at that time. Onely I made this breife answere: that if some truth be not to be preached at all times, yet the CONTRARY vnto truth was to be preached at no time: and if it be lawfull for any man to impugne it, is it not lawfull for me to defend, it and especially, when it concerneth my selfe in particular? For so it did in this case: the eye of the whole vniuersity being cast vpon me in this behalfe.

Thus I tooke my leaue of M. Vicechancellour, he being full of passion and I of resolution for this matter: against which he declamed with many words, and without any reason; consorting herin with those furious Donatists, of whō S. Augustine pronounceth truly:Contra lit. Petil. l. 2. c. 51. Quid hoc aliud es • , quàm nescire quid dicere, & tamen non posse nisi maledicere?

div.head: CHAP. III. The finall proceedings of D. King, and his assistents against me, and my doctrine.
div.p: THIS Magistrate intending a preposterous course against me, & yet pretending a formality of iustice, conuented me before him in iuridicall manner, vpon the vigill of S. PETER, a practitioner of my doctrine. Lord (said he) vvhat shall vve haue, that haue forsaken all, and follovved thee?

Other Doctours (of better vvorth) vvho heard my Sermons vvere not called vnto my triall; vvhereas 2 onely of these six Iudges vvere my Auditours.Appearing now vpon my summons, I found M. vicechancellour assisted with 5. compeeres; D. Airay, D. Aglionbee, D. Hutton, D. Harding, D. Benefield; a selected company for his owne humour. VVho as they were generally to be excepted against by me, as incompetent Iudges: so in special D. Hutton for his inueterate malice conceiued against me longe since vpon a base, & vnworthy respect. D. Benefield, as he was my principal opposite,Quid mihi dabis. &c. so he, with the rest, being a doctrinall Caluinist could neuer afford me an equall triall in this issue, depēding vpon the FATHERS; which he, & they, do really disclayme.

These petty Iudges being thus assembled; M. vicechancellour inueighed against me with a bitter, & passionate speach, contayning in it these capitall accusations. First; that I had lately preached scandalous, & erroneous Doctrine. Secōdly; that I was vehemently suspected of POPERY, & that, by this doctrine, I had now iustified the suspition. Thirdly; that I had brought an infamy vpon the vniuersity, and in speciall
vpon him, and his house. VVherfore I must expect a censure according to my demerit.

To the first I answered, that as vpon sufficient discouery of the pretended errour, I would recant it (since I sought nothing but the aduancement of truth) so I should consequently acknowledge that I had giuen the scandall if I haue preached the errour. But my conscience telleth me, that I haue offended neither in matter, nor manner; substance, nor circumstance.

To the second; that men might suspect what they pleased, & that it lay not in me to hinder euery supition. As for the imputation of Popery in this point, it cleaueth vnto the Scripture, & all Antiquity from which (ioyntly) I assumed this Popish doctrine.

To the third; that as he, and his house could receiue no infamy by such a truth, so much lesse the vniuersity; forasmuch as the best in iudgment there, (if not the most in number also) concurred with me in this point.

Here D. Aglionbee suddainly interrupted me; demaunding, who they were; and, making me the trumpetter onely of other mens opinions, he said, that I was set on by some, who, though they affected this, and other such like points of Popery, yet they dare not broach them themselues, but whosoeuer they are, they shall
be mett with all either in schooles, or pulpit.

This is the Miles gloriosus, who challendgeth his betters for POPERY;At Metton Coll. before a great assembly. but they are able, and will confidently appeach him, not only of Iouinian heresy (which he defended expressely against S. Hierome) but of sondry other blasphemies, & Heresies, which he preached publikely in S. Maries Churche: the particulars whereof I haue seene in wryting.

These things I could haue then obiected vnto him. But being not willing now to exasperate him, or any other there present, I returned him my answere in this manner. Sir; it may suffice you now to vnderstand, that there are such men in this vniuersity, that wil constantly defend this doctrine: who they are, I leaue it vnto your inquiry; you may finde them out by getting a generall subscription here vnto your opinion, or by some other meanes. Onely, to giue you farther assurance of there resolution in this point, it pleased some of them freely (without my desire or knowledge) to draw a letter, wherin they recommended me, and my cause vnto the Archbishopp of Canterbury; informing his Grace, that the doctrine was most cleare on my side, and that they would stand in publick iustification therof.

But I pray you, Sir. to be aduertised by me; that I neuer made vse of their letters: one
reason wherof meeteth with your obiection. For as I assumed this doctrine from the holy Scriptures, and ancient Fathers, so I determined to maintaine it vpon these grounds, without any assistance: and much lesse was I set on by any of them.

And that you may know vpon what authority I first beganne, and do now procede; here are the Doctours (24 in number 12. Greeke 12. Latine) who set me on; here are their testimonies; produce their bookes; conuince me if you can.
VVhereat his courage beganne to abate; & first he excepted against me for producing the Greeke, in whose language (said he) you haue but slender skill.

To which malitious, and impertinent exception, I answered first; that it was sufficient for me to rely vpon the translations approued commonly in the Church. Secondly;Do not many Deuines in England, and the people generally rely vpon the Translation of scriptures vvhose originall they vnderstand not? that I had so much skill in Greeke, as to compare the translation with the originall, and that none there was so exact, as to vnderstand some Greeke fathers (& namely S. Gregory Nazianzen) in their natiue idiome. Thirdly; that if I had no Greeke Authour on my side; yet here is a sufficient Iurie of Latine Fathers, whose language I vnderstand, & whose conspiring tenent, I hope, you dare not renounce.

Doctour Aglionbee being thus pressed by me & hauing nothing to answere in his owne defence; D King interposed himselfe; obiecting that D. Hutton had inhibited me: that D. Benefield (whose bookes I was not worthy to cary) had publiquely confuted my doctrine &c. whith such like friuolous allegations.

As for D. Hutton his inhibition I answered as before; adding farther that I respected not his iudgment in this matter. For I knew (indeede) that as his vnderstanding is not very deepe, so his affection is not very good; who, in a certaine booke (or rather statizing pamphlet) concerning the crosse in baptisme; defēdeth this laudable Christian ceremonie by tradition of the Church, as it is witnessed by the holy Fathers: and yet now in a point of greater importance, expressed in scripture, taught by Fathers, practised by the Saints, defined by the whole Church, he blushed not to accuse me, nay S. GREGORY himself of Popery in this doctrine. But singular is my comfort to consider, by what Iudge, I am thus vsed, in what cause, and with what Patrone; from whom our Nation first receiued her first faith, & for whose faith I must now forsake my nation.

As for D. Benefeild with his lecture, and his bookes, I passed them ouer: considering that M. Vicechācellour made excursions from the
point, loading me only with contumely and disgrace.

VVherfore, not suffering him to diuert me from the mayne issue, I desired him to deale punctually, that is to say, first to admitt a triall by the Fathers, or to deny it: if he denyed it, he should be therby sufficiently conuinced. Secōdly; if he admitted this trial,Haeretici est praecepta Patrum declinare; saith vvorthy Flauian in his first epist to LEO the Great. then either to disprooue my authorities, or to approoue my doctrine.

But he not daring to make a briefe, & punctuall answere to my reasonable demaundes, fell extrauagantly into a mention of the reformed Churches; summoning me before their tribunall, for the censuring of this doctrine.
VVhich course of proceeding, I vtterly disclaymed, as vnequall; because the later Church is not to iudge the former, but cōtrarily the former is to iudge the later.

And what did I herein (good Reader) but obserue the prescription of Antiquity in this behalfe,Cōtra Iulian Pelag. lib. 1. & namely that of S. Augustine against the Pelagian hereticks; PATRES oportet vt populi Christiani vestris nouitatibus anteponāt, eis{que} potius eligant adhaerere, quàm vobis?

Here D. Airay distasting my refusall to stand vnto the verdict of the reformed Churches, questioned with me about the rule of my faith; I answered him breifly; that I wholly followed
Vincentius Lyrinensis his direction;Cōtra haeref cap. 1. &c See D. Field. pag. 239. to witt, Canonicall scripture, and Ecclesiasticall tradition; the first being sensed by the second.

This rule he called Popish, exclayming against it as the very ground of Popery, & superstition. VVhereupon I desired him (for my better instruction) to giue a rule of faith more certaine, & infallible then this, which he branded with such disgracefull imputation.

VVhy (said he) vvhat other ground of faith, then the pure vvord of God? I demaunded then; who shall interpret this word? He replyed; the spirit. Vvhat spirit good Sir? The spirit of God only which priuate men thinke they haue? Against which rule I excepte, for that it was the common plea of all condemned Heretiques. Vvherefore I required a triall of this pretended spirit; for I can not admitt that to be God his spirit in any priuate man, which consenteth not with the spirit of the Catholique Church. And thus you see M. D. Airay that what you formerly reiected out of my rule, as Popish, you must necessarily admit as true; that is: Ecclesiasticall Tradition annexed to the sacred Canon for the discerning of priuate spirits. Otherwayes each Heretique will sense scripture in the mould of his owne brayne.

And now M. D. Airay being thus ouerthrowne in the rule of his faith, proposed vnto
me a question of capitall daunger; wishing M. Vicechancellour to question me vpon the poynt of the kings SVPREMACY; for surely (said he) you shall find him vnsound therin.

But M. Vicechancellours thoughts caried him so farre away at that present, that he gaue no eare vnto this impertinēt, & bloudy question: but prosecuting the vindictiue designement (formerly cōcluded vpon betwixt D. Aglionbee, & himselfe who held a secret conference together) he resumed his old accusations of false, erroneous, scandalous, and Popish doctrine: for deliuering, and reinforcing whereof, I deserued the seuerity of Iustice.
Perceiuing now their resolution to punish me without farther examination of my cause, or respect of my iust defence, I finally proposed vnto them these two demaunds.

FIRST; that they would proceede against me iuridically, & by way of Articles; so I should know precisely what was the errour, and falsehood of my Doctrine; and they should receiue my answere made in forme of law. For this hath euer bene the custome of proceding in this vniuersity, and in God his Church.
Hereunto M. Vicechancellour replyed. VVhat? Articles? you shall haue articles time inough: meane vvhile, I say that all (meaning my Sermon) is false; scandalous, Popish, erroneous. &c.

My SECOND demaund therupon was; that he, and his associates would condescend vnto this small request; to witt; I will here set downe this affirmatiue proposition; SVNT EVANGELICA CONSILIA; & subscribe vnto it in your presence. May it please you also to sett downe the negatiue, NON SVNT EVANGELICA CONSILIA; and subscribe your seuerall names thereunto; and signify therewithall, that you haue punished me for teaching the contrary assertion.

This request, D. King not onely denyed, but also exclaymed against me for making this petition. And no meruayle; for he that durst neuer, throughout this whole proceeding, formally, and by expresse mention, condemne Euangelicall Counsayles; how could he yeald vnto any such subscription? whereby he and the rest might haue remayned HERETIQVES vpon thiere owne record.

The conclusion of all was this, M. Vicechancellour beating me downe with the blow of authority (hauing no other meanes to conuince me) pronounced his definitiue sentence against me; which I wil here relate word for word, as neere as I could possibly beare it away.

M. Leech; for preaching scandalous, and erroneous doctrine (Doctrine, as you vvell knovv, stiffly
defended by the Church of Rome, He named none, but (as I conceiue) this vvas one: viz The virginall estate excelleth the cōjugall An • thus you may see; Fo • tis est REX sed fortior Mulier. 3. Esdr. 3. and vvhereupon many absurdities do follovv) I do first as VICECHANCELLOVR silence you from preaching. Secondly; as DEANE of this house, I suspend you from your commons and function here for the space of tvvelue moneths. This is my sentence; and before these my Associates I require you to take notice thereof.

Vvhich sentēce though it were tyrannicall & vniust, yet it no wayes discouraged me, but rather confirmed me in my opinion. wherefore I protested the doctrine againe more resolutely, then before; wishing M. Vicechancellour, & his assistants to vnderstād thus much from me. First: that I held the doctrine with asmuch, nay more confidence then euer I did. Secondly: that I farther concluded the inuincibility of the point out of the manner of their proceedings, whereat they were driuen into the extremity of furie, and passion.

Thus the assembly was dissolued, and I, putting M. Vicechancellour in mind of the Articles (which he formerly promised, and bade me now to expect within two, or three dayes) tooke my leaue for that time.

And now (courteous Reader) since thou hast seene the proceedings of theis men, consider with me,In ps. Cōtra partem Donati. w • ether I haue not iust cause to complayne against them as S. Augustine cōplayned
longe before against the Donatisticall faction.

q.l: Fe • erunt quod voluerunt tunc in illâ caecitate:
Non Iudices sederunt, non Sacerdotes de more,
Quod solent in magnis causis congregati judicare:
Non accusator, & reus steterunt in quaestione,
Non testes, & documentū: quo possent crimē probare.
Sed Furor, Dolus, Tumultus: qui regnant in falsitate.

div.p: VVherefore I conclude this whole passadge with the burthen of that excellent psalme: Omnes qui gaudetis de pace, modò VERVM judicate.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Hovv D. King dealt injuriously vvith me, and perfidiously, concerning the ARTICLES vvhich should expresse some crimes particularly objected against me.
div.p: Act. 25.27.VVHEN S. Paul had appealed vnto the tribunall of CAESAR: Festus (the deputy) thought it an vnreasonable thing to send a prisoner vnto his Lord, and not to signify the cause. For thus the light of nature could teach an Heathen, that, in discretion, and in iustice no man should be called into question, without a pretense (at the least) of some speciall crime.

But see now a Christian Magistrate inferiour
vnto an heathen in his behalfe: who did not onely conuent, but condemne me: and neuer signified the cause: which yet could be none other, then that which concerned S. Paul himselfe: CONSILIVM DO &c.1. Cor. 7.25.

Howbeit, if he had dealt with me according to the law of the Corinthians (an heathen people) & had tried my cause equally,Boem. de mor. gentium. after he had inflickted punishment vpon my person, yet then also there had bene some shew of iustice in his proceedings.

But see now farther, how he is inferiour vnto heathens in this respect: nay yet more: how he added perjury vnto his iniustice. For whereas he promised to deliuer ARTICLES vnto me, which should containe (precisely) the cause of his former seuere sentēce against me, yet when (according to his owne appointement) I came vnto him personally to require them, he denied absolutely that he had euer made any such promise. And when I pressed him more particularly thereunto, adding al circūstances (of time, place, persons &c.) so that he could not haue any semblable euasion, he desperately forsware himselfe: saying (with many ingeminations) VPON MY FAITH,Fides Punica. I neuer promised you any ARTICLES; you belie me. &c.

VVhen I perceiued what small conscience he made either of faith in his promise, or of
equity in his proceedings, I desyred him with many earnest obtestations, that it would please him, at the least, to signify vnto me now by word of mouth, expressely what that point is, for which he had thus punished me to my disgrace, and losse. And this fauour I humbly requested at his hands asmuch for the general, as my owne particular satisfactiō. For many saw the punishmēt, but could not know the cause.

This petition was reinforced in my name by a graue, and ancient M. of Arts; who pleaded to obtaine the same in regard of Iustice, VVisdome, and Charity, Iustice; because (sayd he) it was the forme of law, that the party accused should answere articulately vnto the crime obiected.See Act. 25.16 vt accus •
tus locum d • fendendi accipiar ad a •• uenda or mina, quae ei obijciuntur. Vvisedome; that you may deliuer your selfe from the suspition of iniury; & especially since the whole Vniuersity is much distracted vpon these late proceedings. Charity; that you may rectify M. Leech his vnderstāding by a proper conuiction of his supposed errour. And I dare promise in his behalf,To punish vvithout instruction, it is tyranny. Salust. that if you can conuince his iudgement, he will recant the doctrine; for I haue heard him often protest thus much.

Theis reasons, and persuasions of my friend, entered so deepely into M. Doctour Kings heart for the present, that he promised to conuent me againe, and that he would proceede with
me according to my desire herein. Notwithstanding he violated this promise also to his exceeding great disreputation.

But I come now vnto his answere, which he made vnto my former humble petition. Sir. (said he) it shall satisfy you, and the vniuersity, that I HAVE DONE IT; take your remedy, where you can. If I haue vvronged you heere, right your self elsevvhere.

This was spoken like a KING deed; and not like a subiect; who though he be a Magistrate ouer others, yet should be subordinate vnto a common Law, and Lord. And happy are those gouermēts, where the wise sentence of an heathen Poet is not neglected.Horat.
This was my last refuge, and finall hope; but how farre I was deceiued in my iust expectation, the sequele shal declare.Chap. 6.

div.head: CHAP. V. Hovv I vvas summoned to S. Paules Crosse, and defeated. D. Kings conference vvith a learned Doctour in London, about Euangelicall Counsailes.
div.p: BEING now silenced by the Vicechancellour from preaching within the precincts of the vniuersity, so that I could not exercise my function neither in the publique audience of the learned, nor yet in any of the parish Churches (which I had vsually visited, by course, euery sabboth, and holy day; vnlesse some speciall occasion diuerted me from my customable practise) I receaued letters from the Lord Bishopp of London (my very Honourable, and much respected freind; whom it pleased freely to bestow that place vpon me, in regard of my first sermon preached in Oxford, from which his successour had now suspended me for the last) wherein his Lordshipp required me to preache at S. Paules crosse, and not to fayle at the time prefixed in his summons. VVherevpon I prepared my selfe accordingly, & certifyed his Lordshipp thereof, as he had enioyned me in his said letters.

The Vicechancellour, getting notice of these summons, sent for me immediately, and requested that he might haue a view of the Bishoppes Letters; which, in courtesy, I then communicated vnto him, howbeit I had iust reason to suspect (for his countenance expressed much perturbation in his heart) that he would plott some meanes to hinder this designement. And as (in all probability) he did
coniecture that I would haue constantly asseuered my former doctrine in the greatest audiēce of the kingdome, so I must acknowledge that this was my resolued determination.

But Maister D. King fearing least with so publick a promulgation of this truth, I should also blazon his shame (which now neither Oxford, nor London, nor our diuided world it selfe shall containe within hir limitts) handled the matter so by his policy, and authority, that my lord of London (through his misinforming suggestions) countermaunded the former by second letters; dischardging me from the performance of that duty. And now Maister Vicechancellour thought that he had not onely inconuenienced me, but also secured himselfe.

For this end, and purpose also he repayred then vnto a Doctour of principall place, and eminent worth (a man not vnder any; if not ouer all) with whom he intertayned longe discourse touching the Doctrine of Euangelicall Counsailes; complayning that in Oxford, it had bene lately broached, and obstinately defended. And now, I pray you, good Sir (said he) vvhat is your opinion concerning this point?

Here by the way, giue me leaue (good Reader) to propose two things vnto thy discreete consideration. FIRST; that D. King either
had no knowledge at all, or not well grounded in that point, wherein he condemned me by violence of authority, and not by force of reason. SECONDLY; that as I suffred with a good cōscience, so he punished me with an euill. For I had not the least scruple, nor diffidence in this point. Al testimonies, diuine, humane; of God, and of his Chuch, did firmely establish me therein. And therfore, though I conferred with many learned men vpon the same, yet I neuer demaunded of any man, by way of doubt; Sir. vvhat is your opinion &c. but, I alwayes said; This is the Doctrine of all the Fathers; this is the iudgment of the vvhole Church; it is founded vpon sacred Scripture &c. vvill you stand to it, or vvil you disclayme it? whereupon I commonly receiued this answere; the doctrine is true in it selfe, though not seasonable for these times. But Maister D. King hauing not any such certainty of infallible grounds, could not but fluctuate in the instability of his priuate iudgment.

To returne now vnto the conference of M. Vicechancellour with the aforesaid Doctour; he receiued a cold satisfaction vnto his hott demaund. For the doctour, wondering that any difficulty should be made in this matter, answered presently without any demurre; there are EVANGELICALL COVNSAILES; and no doubt can be made thereof.

And what was (thinke you) Doctour Kings reply vnto this graue, and confident assertion? Did he dispute against it? no; he could not. Did he gaynsay it? no; he durst not. Thus the renowned pulpit-Doctour, that could domineere ouer his poore inferiour, censure him, depraue him, vilify him with intollerable reproaches (such as he feared not to vtter, but I am ashamed to mention) stoode mute; not daring to disclose his opinion, which he could not iustify by any waight of reason.

Now, if Doctour King will stand in deniall hereof, or any other be in doubt of my report, I protest, in the faith of a Catholique man, that I write this from the immediate relation of the Doctour himselfe, vnto whom I was ledd by the conduct of my good Angell; Farther, I am so well perswaded of his resolute iudgment, and honest heart, that I dare boldy say; Doctour King shal neuer be able to procure his subscription against this doctrine.

div.head: CHAP. VI. My appeale vnto the Archbishoppe of Canturbury; & hovv episcopally it pleased his Grace to deale in the Matter.
div.p: AS I alwayes had comfort in my wronges, because I suffred for righteousnes sake; so I conceiued good hope, that the superiour Magistrate would rectify the proceedinges of his inferiour. Vvherfore, being oppressed with the iniuries of the Vicechancellour, I appealed vnto the Archbishoppe; thinking that his house had bene as Hierusalem, when iustice and iudgment vvere lodged therein.

Being admitted into his Graces presence, I vnfoulded the whole processe of this businesse; acquainting him first, with the doctrine, which I had preached. Secondly, with the groundes, and reasons wherevpon I built the same. Thirdly; with the intertainment, which it, and I for it, had found within the vniuersitie of Oxford.

The maine summe of his answere cōsisted in these two particulars. First; that he must defend the estimation of his vicechancellour, of whom a good opinion was generally conceiued.19. 21. vade, vende omnia cte. Secondly; that the text of S. Math. (commonly alleadged for that purpose) doth not afford the doctrine of Euangelicall Counsailes. And here his Grace (falling into Caluins false, and absurd exposition) sayd, that our Sauiour doth not here giue any Counsayle of Pouertie, but onely dismasked the hipocrisy of the yong man, being a proud, boasting Pharisee &c.

My whole reply was, that as I sought not the impeachment of his vicechancellours credit, farther then he had wronged it him selfe by his indirect proceedinges, so, if I could not make my accusations good against him, I would be content to sustaine my former punishment, with a greater augmentation.

As for the text of S. Matth. I expounded it by S. Marke: who saith that Christ beholding the young man, loued him; which loue of Christ did cleare him from all suspition of hypocrisy, and dissimulation. Besides; I humbly intreated his Grace to remitt him selfe, & me, vnto the generall consent of Antiquity in this matter.

Here Doctor Barlovv interposed his verdict: whom if I had knowne aswel by his face, as I knew him by his sermō, I had then appeached as a man of little honesty, or conscience: because he (in a sermon preached before his Ma
• estie at Hampton Court, concerning the authoritie of Bisshopps) doth iustify the distinction betwixt Precepts, & Counsayles; pag. fourth: before the end. citing a text of S. Paul to that effect; & yet now,1. Cor. 7.25. seing his Grace of Cāterburie disaffected towards this doctrine, • e also spake agianst it. And thus it pleased D. Shavv (who proclaymed the Earle of Essex his Cales triumphe, and his London ruine) to crosse • im selfe with a flatt contradiction, rather
to dissent from his assertion, by whose fauour he had mounted into the chayre of Honour.

Many occurrences there passed at that time; with the recapitulation whereof I will not now surchardge this little treatise. In conclusion; my Lord of Canturbury demaunded a copy of my sermon; which I deliuered vnto Maister Barcham (one of his Chaplaines) together with the authorities, which do hereafter ensue.In the end of all.

The sermon was receiued, the authorities were returned vnto me againe: which made me thinke, that my cause should neuer come vnto an indifferent triall. And truly I sawe no probability of any triall. For though I gaue continual attendance at Lambeth, for the space of fifteene, or sixteene dayes, yet I was fedde with delayes, to my iust griefe and great expense.

Vvherefore, seing no hope of redresse, where it lastly remayned, and was iustly expected, I retyred my selfe vnro some priuatenesse; recollecting my thoughtes in meditation beetwixt God, and my owne soule.

And now, in the sweetenesse of contemplation, hauing God onely for the obiect of my comfort, I tooke an intellectuall reueiw of my cause, and all circumstances of the fore passed
Businesse; commending the whole vnto God, the great & soueraigne Iudge. For I had now resolued to be no farther troublesome vnto his Grace of Canterbury, who had so little respect of truth, and no greater compassion of my wronges.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Hovv being retired vnto priuate meditation, J vvas found out by the Archbishoppe his Chaplayn, & solicited by him to see his Lord. My resolution vpon a better course.
div.p: VVHEN I had now remayned a fortnight space in my priuate meditations, his Graces Chaplaine (accompanied with a Doctour of deuinity) made diligent enquiry after me; and finding me out,D. Childerly; vvho is a Chaplayn also vnto his Grace. he demaunded of me what was the reason of my long absence from his Lord; who (as he said) would write his letters effectually vnto his Vicechancellour for our reconciliation: so that I should be relieued, & restored aswel vnto my former liberty of preaching, as vnto the fruition of my place.

R • g • 5.But here I remembred the answere of IEHV vnto the question of IORAM. Is it peace Iehu? vvhat peace (said he) vvhile the fornication of Iezabel, thy mother, and her vvitchcraftes are yet in force? So, what reconciliation, vvhat peace betwixt me, and D. King, while truth was thus suppressed, and his heresy (worse then vvitchcraft) stoode yet in force?

Wherefore, after significatiō of my thankful minde to his Lord shippe, who now vouchsafed in some sorte, to commiserate my vniust vexations: I answered, that I had greater respect of the cause, for which I suffred, then of the punishmēt, which I did sustaine: assuring M. Barcham, that restitution vnto my place was not the principall part of my desire.

For as God did require of me the constant iustification of his eternal truth, so I could not but require it also at their hands, who by their functiō (as Ministers) & dignity (as Bishopps) were specially obliged thereunto.

VVhereas he pressed me farther, with motiues of profit, and that I hindred the course of my preferment, by contending against the authority of Magistrates (vvho as he said, must stand one vvith an other) my reply was to this effect, that I desired not to rise where truth must fall vertue is the pathe to Honour: Heauen must not be lost for earth: the plenty of riches
doth not recōpence the emptines of the soule: a good conscience is a continuall feast.

As for the magistrates I reuerenced their persons, and honoured their places; knowing that their povver is from God, but designed for the preseruation of his truth: which if I impugned, let them strike me with the sworde of Iustice: but if they withstood it, yet, I must defend it with courage, as also I shall suffer for • t with patience. For I alwayes had the counsayle of the wise man before mine eyes,Ecclus. 4. Striue for the TRVTH vnto death &c.

VVhich resolution in me though it sorted not with his liking, nor yet (perhapps) was expected frō a poore, oppressed scholler (whom his vncharitable aduersaries had determined either to bowe, or breake) yet he importuned me, at the least to see his Lord, and not to neglect his fauourable inclinatiō to do me good.

VVhereupon I made a shew that I would • hortly visite his Grace. And this I did, because I did probably collect, that my intention was by some meanes disclosed vnto him; whereby I might be defeated of that course, vpō which I was now wholly resolued.

For me thought that God did speake with
• n my heart, as he spake sometimes vnto Abraham his seruant. Go foorth of thy land, Gen. 12.1. and from thy kindred, and from thy fathers house, and come into
the land, vvhich I shall shevv vnto thee. For, can any Church, or any faith be in that land, where the very grounds, and principles of ancient Christianity are dissolued, where there is no certaine foundation to builde Religion vpon? VVhere euery mans power is his reason to make good his Doctrine? VVhere an iniury sustayned for the truth, can find no redresse without treasonable conniuency to see the truth oppressed?

But I will pretermitt (good Reader) here to make a speciall enumeration of my Motiues, drawing me vnto my finall resolutiō; for they will ensue orderly in the third, and last part of this Treatise. Onely consider (with me) now, with what conflict of flesh, and bloud I could intertayn this resolution, to come out of my Land, and from my kindred, and from my Fathers hovvse; with what grief I could forsake a noble Vniuersity, the company of my kindest friends, the comfort of my dearest familiars; other emoluments, which such a place doth actually yeald, and prepareth vnto greater.

Howbeit (my Brethren) since there is banishment indeed, where no place is left for truth, I esteeme all theis thinges as dongue, that I may gayne Christe; for he is my sufficient reward I did not conceiue that when I preached my doctrine amōg you, I should haue giuen you such
an example thereof in mine owne person. But thancks be vnto him who disposeth all thinges sweetely for the benefite of his children.

Finally (my brethren) I wish that you may enioy your contrey, which is aboue, without forsaking that, which is belowe. But if you cannot, by reason of the time; then looke vp vnto your eternity; let not your excellent spiritts abase themselues vnto the loue of trāsitory thinges; For behold I shevv you a more excellent vvay. 1. Cor. 12.11.

div.head: THE THIRD PART Contayning 12. Motiues, vvhich persvvaded me to embrace the Catholicke Religion. Briefely, and naturally deriued out of the premises.
div.p: S. AVGST. In psal. contra partem Donati Sitis Catholica quid sit, & quid sit praecisum à vite: Si qui sint inter vos cauti, veniant, & viuant de radice.

div.head: To the conscionable, and Ingenious Reader.
div.p: THOVGH the generall motiues vnto the Catholique Religion, are many, and vvaightie; yet the particular, vvhich issued out of this present businesse, vvere such, as cōvinced my vnderstanding, and svvayed my affection to approue, and embrace the same.

ƲƲherefore (courteous Reader) aswel to procure thy good, as to iustify my selfe, and to satisfy others, J haue communicated them vnto thy vievv. For matter; they are the same novv, as vvhen J conceiued them in the beginning: for māner; they are brought forth in somevvhat a different shape.

Thus much may suffice for thy instruction concerning these Motiues. Onely J may not forget to aduertise thee; that whereas through out their titles, J vse this perpetuall stile: The Protestantes &c. (hovvbeit
the most learned amongst them, differ in iudgement from the common sort: and in this respect, cannot be cōcluded in the generality of all) I haue not done this vvithout good consideration.

For though the principall deuines in England, do vtterly distast the vayne opinions of D. King, and such like; yet, since by publique profession of the truth, they giue not sufficient notice vnto the vvorld of their Catholique positions, J must inuolue them also in this cōmon accusation. And as they, against their knovvledge, do suffer a preiudice to fall vpon God his truth,Corde creditur ad iustitiam; ore fit confessio ad salutem they must likevvise, against their vvil, suffer an infamy to remaine vpon their ovvne persons.

div.head: The first Motiue. The Protestants admit not a triall of their Religion by the testimony of the Fathers; vvhatsoeuer they pretend to the contrary.
div.p: BECAVSE it is a preposterous deuise to iudge the former ages of the Churche by the later;D. Field. pag. 204. VVe VVillingly admitt a triall by the Fathers; sayth he in the name of his Church. therefore the courses of my study haue euer bene directed vnto a diligēt perusal of ancient Fathers; whose authority, simply cōsidered, as it may prepōderate our moderne writers; so, in reference vnto the Church, being her witnesses (who is the iudge to define all controuersies) their testimonie is to be preferred before all Authours whatsoeuer.

Neither resolued I thus without serious deliberation; & especially, the graue counsayle of Vincentius Lyrinensis did preuayle with me,cōtra haeres. cap. 1. & 2. saying, that learned & holy men did generally conspire in this opinion: If any man wil discerne Hereticall prauity from Catholike verity, he must be furnished with a double helpe; first the Canon of sacred scripture: Secondlie the tradition
of the Catholique Churche: wherein three thinges inseparably concurre; Vniuersalitie, Antiquitie, Consent.

The reason of which prescriptiō is yealded by him to be this. The scripture is sublime; &, forasmuch as all men sense it not alike, it is necessarie to adioyne thereunto the continuall interpretation of the Church.
Vpon this infallible ground (euident vnto all men of any apprehension) I builded my faith; conforming it alwayes vnto those Orthodox principles, which I had deriued out of the venerable Fathers.

Hence I assumed this doctrine of Euangelicall Counsailes, which as I deliuered out of the sacred volumes of Antiquity; so Antiquity it selfe deduced it (with me) out of the diuine Oracles of holy scripture. And therfore seeing that my opiniō was clearly built vpon this fundation, I pressed it vncessantly, vntill my vniust Iudges were enforced to forsake this meanes of tryall, and, consequently to punish the Fathers in me, as I had spoken by them.

But when I plainly sawe, that my doctrine could not be condemned without condemnation of the auncient Church, & that my Iudges were driuen to this extremity, I inferred, that their Religion could not be good; & that their consciences vvere verie badde.

div.head: The second Motiue. The Protestants perferre their Reformed Congregations, before the ancient CATHOLIQVE Churche.
div.p: AS my violent Iudges did palpably disclayme the sentēce of the anciēt Church, so they vnreasonably required my submission vnto their reformed Congregations; which, as they be not comparable with the purity of the former, so their principall Doctours (Luther & Zvvinglius; men no lesse odious eache vnto the other, then both are hateful vnto the Church of Rome) are no wayes matchable with the Patrones of my doctrine.S August. S. Ambros. S. Hierom.

For as S. Gregory Nazianzen iustly excepted against the Arrians in this manner;S, Gregory. Epistola 1. ad C •• do •• contra Arrianos. If our faith be but 30. yeares ould (400. yeares being passed since the incarnation of Christ) then our gospell hath bene preached in vayne; our martyrs haue dyed in vayne vntill this time, &c. So if for a point of faith, I must remit my selfe vnto Luther, Zvvinglius, Caluin & their reformed conuenticles, rather then vnto the holy Fathers, & ancient Church; then surely the gospell hath bene miserably taught, and all our predecessors haue bene
pitifully deceiued for 1600. yeares since.

Singular therefore was the folly, and partiality of my Iudges, to detract authority from our blessed Fathers, & to yealde it vnto Lutherans (men of as new a stampe in these tymes, as the Arriās were in S. Gregory Nazianzē his time) whose carnall appetites, and base condition of life, drew them to allow that in their doctrine which they performed in their practise; being contrary in both vnto the canon of scripture, and continuall succession of the Church.

The consideration wherof did manifestly detect vnto me, that either their vnderstanding is very meane, or their will very peruerse; who feared not to disauthorise the Fathers, & yet would not graunt me the same liberty against their brethren; in whom I neuer approued any thing otherwayes, then it was consonant with the prescription of Antiquity, or dissonant from hir Tradition.

div.head: The third Motiue. The Protestants brand the Catholique doctrine vvith the name of Popery.
div.p:
THE name of PAPISTS was first deuised by a luxurious Apostata; inuentour also of the name of SACRAMENTARIES;Luther.
for so both Catholiques, and Zvvinglians stand indebted vnto him in theis respects.

By the insolency of this man it came to passe, that as many other doctrines, so particularly this, had bene stamped with the imputation of Popery; whence it was that my Caluinian Iudges (calumniating both me and it) were pleased to fasten the note of Popery vpon it, and of a Papist vpon me.

But since my grounds are meerely Catholique (as you see) and since this doctrine it selfe is the common faith of ancient Churche; it followeth, either that it is no Popery, (as these men terme it) or that Popery (truly conceiued) is the very Catholique faith. But of the twoo, the later is more probable.

VVherevpon I inferred this conclusion for my finall resolution; that POPERY was necessarily cōsequent vppon the true grounds of deuinity; & therefore my Iudges betrayed their owne folly in this behalf; for asmuch,VVhat Pope did euer deuise this and many other doctrines, vvhich are called Popery? as by a condemnation of this doctrine, they must ineuitably confesse, that POPERY (well vnderstoode) is the doctrine of Antiquity; and that the Fathers were no lesse Papists herein then my selfe.

div.head: The fourth Motiue. The Protestants subuert the truest meanes of piety, and perfection.
div.p: PERFECTION is not absolute in this life, but graduall; that is to say; men are perfit in a degree: some more, some lesse, according to their cooperation with diuine grace.

To which end, and purpose, there are Consilia perfectionis, Counsailes of perfection; as Vitginitie, Pouertie &c. which remoouing the impediments of perfection, are excellent meanes to cōduct vs therunto; in asmuch as they withdraw vs from the loue of the flesh and of the worlde, which are our capitall enemies assaulting vs with their continuall delights, and pleasures.

But the Protestants (being in the number of them, of whom the Apostle, by prophetick spirit, spake long before; that they vvould not suffer vvholesome doctrine) renounce the aduise of their Sauiour; qui potest capere, capiat; they reiect the monition of S. Paul, consilium do; they cast behind them the common iudgment of ancient Fathers in this point. And whereas themselues are now caried away with the euill current of this worst age; they feare not, not
only to disclayme the Fathers but irreligiously to slander them,D. Benefield in his lecture. as men bevvitched herein vvith the errours of their time.
Hence it is that the plausibility of the first gospell seeketh not to cast any raynes vpon the feruour of nature, but yealdeth passage rather, and helpe vnto her precipitate course,

S. PAVL was of a contrary opinion; witnesse his owne wordes, castigo corpus &c. Antiquity was of an other disposition; witnesse S. Hierom in his epistle vnto Pope Damasus, and vnto the virgin Eustochium. VVitnesse S. Gregory Nazianzen in his funerall oration vpon S. Basill. Carnem logibus fraenauit witnesse the whole quire of ancient Churche; which with a sweete heauēly harmony, aswell in practise, as in doctrine, hath commended vnto vs the restraint of lawfull thinges with a singular austerity of life.

Theis things, being wholly opposite vnto the delicacy of Luthers spirit, are reputed Popish by him, and by his carnall sectaries; whose single faith (not clogged with the burthen of pious workes) can more easily mount vnto heauen. Thus are they lulled a sleepe in the cradle of security, dreaming of a victory without any striuing at all.

Yf this be the way, vnto happinesse, the VVAY it selfe hath misled vs; our guides haue seduced vs; our teachers haue misinformed vs;
the austerity of so many Saints registred in the canon of Gods woord, and recorded in the Calender of the Churche, hath bene practised in vayne; and the late gospell is more profitable then the former.
But whether I may rely more safely vpon the first, or last; I remit me vnto the consideration of any man, that hath the sense of true piety lodged in his breast.

div.head: The fift Motiue. The Protestants corrupt the holy scripture in defence of their opinions.
div.p: THE proper meanes designed by God to conuince Heresie, are two, to witt; sacred scripture; and Ecclesiasticall Tradition. Now because Heretiques are clearely refuted by the second, therfore they flye onely vnto the first, which they depraue, and mangle according to the liberty of their spirits. And this they performe partly in their translations, & partly in their interpretation therof.

Though many examples might be afforded in this kind, yet I need not seeke after further proofe, then this present businesse doth afford, wherof I now intreate. For wheras the
words of our Sauiour are easy, and playne; all men DO NOT receiue this saying (to witt, concerning chastity) they render it thus: all men CANNOT receiue this saying; as though there were such an impossibilitie therein, that the freedome of will concurring with the grace of God, could not subdue the inclinations of corrupt nature.

Hence Luther (the slaue of his affections) saith,Tom. 7. in epist. ad vvolfgang. that the propension of feruent nature in MAN towards a WOMAN is so created by God in his body, that it cannot be extinct by any vovves, & therefore he, that resolueth to liue vvithout a WOMAN, must leaue the name of a MAN, and make himselfe to be plainly an Angell, or spirit. For it is by no meanes granted vnto him by God; so that it is aboue his strength to containe himselfe from a vvoman. And this is by the compulsiue vvord of God, vvilling, and commanding the same.

VVherefore the Counsayle of virginity is intollerable with them, that conceiue such an impossibilitie to fulfill it. To increase, Tom. 5. serm. de matrimō. and multiply, it is not a precept (saith Luther) but it is more then a precept; it is implanted nature; it is as necessary as meate, and drinke. It is no more in the povver of Man to liue vvithout a vvoman, then to be a vvoman, and no man.

In vayne then doth our Sauiour giue his aduise, and S. Paul his Counsayle. For, in Luthers
gospell, it is more then a precept to auoid virginity. And yet my Iudges not admitting it to be a Counsayle, could deny it to be a precept. VVhich yet if it be so; why do they then make lesse conscience to fulfill a PRECEPT, then Catholiques do to follow a COVNSAYLE? for the neglect of the first is a sinne; but it is not so in the second; vnlesse wee tye our selues vnto it by a voluntary vow, being not constrayned therevnto by a necessary commaund.

div.head: The sixt Motiue. The Protestants are Iouinianists, and therefore Heretiques, and not Catholiques, euen for this cause.
div.p:
Heres. 82.S. Augustine (as a Register of the Cathol •
que Churche) doth witnesse that Iouinia •
broached this hereticall fancy,See the perorat of S. August. his treatise. vide Ambros. 10. lib. Epist. epist 80. & 81. contrary to the receiued opinion of the whole Church. There is no more merit in the virginity of Nonnes, and other continent persons, then in chast mariadge.

Counsailes of perfectiō denied by Iouinian.The verie same opinion is defended, and embraced by the Lutherans, and Caluinists; and they both conspire with Iouinian in this hereticall tenent; that there is no greater perfection in a virginall, then in a coniugall estate.

And though it pleaseth Doctour Feild to say;Pag. 14 • . VVE do not approue any priuate opinion of IOVINIAN, contrary to the iudgment of Gods Churche; yet both he, and his Grace of Cant. (who approoued his booke) speake herein against their owne consciēce, yea myne owne experience in this particular businesse informeth me otherwayes then they pretend. And I desire no better witnesse to conuince them then S. Augustine, who writeth of this matter in the name of the vniuersall Churche.

According to whose relation (compared with the generall opinion of Lutherans, and Caluinists) I do confidently affirme, that the Protestants are Heretiques in this behalfe; and that, for this cause (besides many others; which I spare to deale in at this present) they are exiled out of the society of the auncient Catholick Churche.

For S. Augustine protesteth (in the peroration of his aforesaid treatise) that vvhosoeuer doth maintayne any of these Heresies, vvhich he hath recorded before, he is not a CATHOLIQVE Christian; and therefore an Hereticall companion. VVhich censure doth necessarily fall vpon my Caluinian iudges, and vpon all such, as concurre with their irreligious opinion.

div.head: The seuenth Motiue. The Protestants accommodate their Religion vnto the state, and present time.
div.p: AS the formes of Ecclesiasticall gouerments are varied by the Caluinists in sondry places according vnto the state, vnder which they liue, so their Doctrines are framed according to the times, and made sutable vnto the policy of their common wealths. Pipe state; & dance Churche. Religion must haue no coate otherwise, then measure is taken by the State.

A iust experience whereof I had in the passage of this businesse. For as the more grosse, and senselesse Caluinists in England do Heretically confound Euangelicall Counsayles with Legall Precepts, so others, more regardfull of the time, wherein they liue, then of the truthe which they should professe, do willingly yeald (for if they should do otherwayes, they should speake against their iudgment, and conscience) that this distinction is founded in the gospell, and propounded by the Churche; but
they say, that it is not a Doctrine seasonably to be deliuered in theis times.

And might not this statizing reason aswell pleade for Arrius his damnable Heresie, being more generaly disaffected by the state in those times, dum totus mundus ingem • it sub Arrianismo; as S. Hierome speaketh.Contra Lucifer.

But I considered first; that truth is not to be impugned, and suppressed, as the common fury of Caluinists hath euer sought to extinguishe it, to the vttermost of their power. In which respect I found my selfe extraordinarily affected, for the reiection of their heresy in this behalfe. And I trust it was not without speciall motion of that spirit, which breacheth in the whole body of the Catholique Church, and consequently in euery constant member of the same.

Secondly, though time beare the blame, yet men are in the fault; and therefore seeing that the open enimies of truthe did barke, when hir secret frends did hold their peace; I conceiued that it was my duty rather to change the time from euill into good, then to suffer it to growe from euill into worse.

And though some men (assisted with power to punish that, which their peeuish fancie disaffected) did beare me downe by violence, yet I tooke no lesse comfort by this iniurie which
they offred vnto me, thē courage by the course which they helde against my doctrine. For I saw that they rather obserued prophane policy to force me vnto silence, then either shew of iustice or piety in proceeding against my (falsly supposed) crime, or waight of reason in cōuincing my vnderstanding. And why? they are the slaues of time, but not disciples of truth.

div.head: The eight Motiue. The Protestants can patiently suffer the articles of the Creede &c. to be violated: but they are seuere in those thinges, that repugne their vtility, or sensuality vvhatsoeuer.
div.p: EVERIE truth, in respect of God reuealing it, and the Church propounding it, is of equal necessity to be beleeued; howbeit, in respect of the matter it selfe; one truth may be of greater consequence; and dignity then an other. And yet it is not the greatnesse of the matter it selfe, but the manner of reuealing, which tyeth vs to a necessity of beleefe.

I will instance in this present businesse. The distinction of Euangelicall Counsayles from Legall Precepts, is a truth to be accepted vpon necessity of saluation. VVhy? because it is sufficiently reuealed vno vs by God, and fully propounded by the Catholique Church; so that it is either wilfull ignorance, not to knowe it, or extreme obstinacy to withstand it. But yet the Articles of the Creede, which are the first elements of faith, commended vnto vs by Apostolicall tradition, may iustly be reputed more waightie, in respect of the matter, which is handled therin; as namely the descent of Christ into hell. VVhich article of faith, is admirably peruerted by the Ministers in England, in so much as 3. or 4. sondry opinions thereof are freely, & vncontroulably deliuered by them, vnto their simple flockes.

I might instance in their different opinions about the Sacraments, and other high misteries of saluation, wherein fanaticall spirits expatiate without any reproofe. But I willingly pretermit these, and come to other particular points of doctrine, which I preached amongst them without impeachment.

First, against Caluin his hereticall Autotheisme destroying the vnity of the diuine essence, I taught, with the Nicene Creede, and all antiquity; that Christ is Deus de Deo, hauing
the same substance that is in the Father, really communicated vnto him in his eternall generation.

Secondly; with S. Gregory, Damascen, the Greeke, & Latine Churche I taught, that Christ assumed our nature perfit, and complete in the very instant of his conception: contrary to the absurd opinion of diuers Caluinisticall Protestants, who auouch that his incarnation was by temporall degrees, and not by entire perfection in an instant.
Thirdly; that God was only the permissiue, not any impulsiue cause of sinne; though Caluin blaspheme to the contrary, and deride the distinction.

Fourthly, Christ crying out, Deus meus, Deus meus &c. was not in a traunce; he suffred no tormēts of hel; dyed not by degrees (as though his senses decayed by little & little) but in perfit sense, payne, obedience, patience, humility, constancy, he rendred vppe his righteous soule a voluntarie sactifice for sinne. But the cōmon opinion of Caluinistes is contrary vnto this position.Filius & spiritus sanctus quoniā non sunta se diē & horam iudicij nesciūt a se, pater autem quouiama se est cit a se. Hil • r in Math.

Fiftly; Christ was not ignorant of the day of iudgement either as God or man: not as God; for though he knew it not primarily, & originally as of him selfe (being not God of him selfe) yet did he knowe it secondarily by
way of communication from the Father.Respectu or dinis non temporis. Not as Man, for though he did not know it Ex naturâ humanitatis, yet did he know it IN naturâ humanitatis, as S. Gregory distinguisheth.lib. epist. 8. cap. 42. In M • rc. 13.3 • . And this doctrine is contrary to Caluin his blasphemous glosse; to wit, Chistus communem habuit cum Angelis ignorantiam.

These, and many such like doctrines (directly opposite to Caluin his tenents) as he is cōtrary to truth (for though his disciples call him a great light of the gospell, yet I rather approue the censure of D. Hunnius, Caluin Iudaiz. a famous Lutheran, saying, that Caluin is an Angell of darkenesse) could passe vnnoted, & vncontrouled by my Caluinian Iudges, and all other adherents vnto that faction.

VVhy then is this distinction of Preceptes & Counsailes so hatefull vnto the Caluinists? Alas, it toucheth their copy hould; most of them being either maried men, or bēding that way: and therfore let Sacraments, Christ Church &c. be abused, nay let many points of Catholique doctrine be preached by Orthodox deuines, yet they are more attētiue vnto the suppression of this truthe, and the like, which doth more directly concerne their carnall pleasure, and wordly profit.

For they that haue sould themselues to be the exact vassalls of their owne affections, and
other mens wills, are carefull to prouide against any thing right, or wrong; true, or false; which may be preiudiciall therevnto; rather attending what it is which wil maintayne their sensuality, then what is orthodox in sound deuinity.

div.head: The ninth Motiue. The Protestants do vnconscionably impugne the knovvne, and manifest truth.
div.p: SINCE the controuersies of Religion are many in number, and intricate in nature, it was my desire (from the beginning of my paynes in the study of sacred Theology) to find out the true Church, that so I might referre my selfe vnto her decision, and rest within her bosome.

For which cause I wholly employed my selfe in turning ouer the volumes of the auncient Fathers; and whatsoeuer I found clearely expressed by their vniforme testimony; I accepted that (according to Vincentius his rule) as the iudgment of the Churche.

Amongst other Doctrines (which seeme Popish vnto the new Euangelists) I receiued this
particular from their instruction; so clearly taught, so conformably witnessed, so ioyntly approoued, that, if the grounds of Religion be not vncertain, then this Doctrine is absolutely free from all exception. And for proofe hereof, I remit me vnto the sentences of the Fathers, wherwith I thought it meete to conclude this discourse.

VVherefore, since they that glory in the Fathers (and want neither witt, nor learning for this matter) do impugne this doctrine, and punish her professours; how can I thinke, that they do not fight against their conscience, & reason? And how can I thinke that any truth will find intertaynement at their hands, when this truth so potent, and so irrefragable: is thus fondly reiected by my Caluinian iudges?

But whom haue they condemned? me? a brother some times of their gospell, a graduate of their schooles, a Minister of their Church? No; but in me, and with me, reuerend Antiquity, the gray headed Fathers, the venerable Doctours, yea holy scripture it selfe is censured by my vnworthy iudges.

VVherefore, as Ieremiah, See Apolog: Iusti Caluinij pag. 11.12. the Patriarch of Constantinople, wrote vnto the Lutherans, so may I testify, and proclayme vnto these men. The ancient deuines, vvho vvere the light of the Church, you intreate at your ovvne pleasure; honouring
& extolling them in vvords but reiecting them in deede; endeuoring to shake them out of our hands, vvhose holy and diuine testimonies vvee should vse against you. VVee see that you vvil neuer submitte your selues vnto the truth.

Finally, as the Patriarch concludeth, that he will haue no intercourse with the Lutherans, forasmuch as he is taught by S. Paul to auoyd an heretick, after the first, or second admonition, so I (being persecuted by men of this condition) am bound to auoyde them; knowing (as S. Paul speaketh) that such (as they) are condemned by their ovvne iudgements.

div.head: The tenth Motiue. The Protestants, for vvant of better meanes to conuince the Catholiques, propose vnto them questions of capitall daunger.
div.p: I HAVE often heard the Catholiques complaine, that, where as they are persecuted for righteousnesse sake, and for their Religion; yet they are traduced with the crime of obstinacy, disobedience, treason, and such like odious imputations.

But aboue the rest, their iust greife (arising
from vniust vexations, did seeme to deserue great compassion, forasmuch as their life, and liuelyhood is allwayes in the mercy of a most vnmercifull law, touching Reconciliation and the SVPREMACY; matters of high, and capitall nature.

Touching the later of these two, I can say more,Doctour •
ray. because the bloudy heart of a Caluinist did seeke my ruine & subuersion thereby. For wheras, in my sermons, I continually gaue this stile vnto his excellent Maiestie; viz. in all causes, and aboue all persons, for iustice, and iudgment, supreme Head, and Gouernour; the Caluinist suspecting me not to stand throughly affected to the kings Supremacy, according to the purport of the law (whereby his Maiestie hath asmuch spirituall Iurisdictiō, as euer the Pope, de facto, 26. Hent 8. chap. 1. 1 Edvvard 6 I Elizab. See theis things excellently discoursed a C • th. Deuine against the fift part of Sir. Ed. • ookes Reports. had in England; and, by vertue of his said supremacy, power of Excommunication is graunted by the lord Chancellour vnto the Delegates vpon Appeales, from the Archbishopp of Canterbury his courts.) wished M. Vice chancellour to examine me vpon this point, & to require my opinion therein.
VVhich seueritie though it was then declined, yet if that other Caluinist had bene in office (as lately he was) all men may easily conceiue into what extremity of perill I had bene cast.

For though I euer did, and shall attribut • that right vnto his Majestie, which, by the law temporall (not dissenting from law diuine) is annexed vnto his imperiall crowne; yet I must cōfesse that I did purposely moderate his title of Supremacy (as the law hath established it) because I allwayes conceiued, that the stile of Defensor fidei (giuen vnto the crowne of England by the Pope) did more properly belong vnto him, then the other, which was translated from the Pope vnto the Crowne, by the violence of a King,Hent. 1. and by the flattery of his subiects.

Caluin in Amos cap. 6. In epist. 54. ad Mycon.And if Doctour Airay had made a conscience of his Maisters iudgment, he would rather haue condescended vnto the equity of my opinion, then sought to draw my life into the certainty of such a danger.

But theis men are so possessed with malice, & adulation, that they rather desire to satisfie their owne passions, & to winne fauour from their Superiours, then to speake, or do according to the truth which pleadeth for it selfe within their corrupt hearts, and dayly accuseth them before the throne of greatest iustice.

div.head: The eleuenth Motiue. The Protestants Manner of proceeding against Catholiques, and Catholique Religion, is absurd in reason, and vnequall in Justice. And hence they are prooued to be Hereticks.
div.p: IN my perusall of the ancient Fathers, and Ecclesiasticall histories, I did very often obserue theis two things. First; that the Catholick Church had wisedome to discerne Hereticall innouations. Secondly; that she had power to enact necessary lawes for the suppression therof; so that an Heresy could not escape hir censure, nor an Heretick hir iustice.

If Popery therefore be Heresy, and Papists Hereticks (as some fanatically brand them) then surely the Catholick Protestāticall Church is able to shew, that shee, in all ages, hath impugned this Heresy, and that she hath her proper lawes to proceede against Hereticall offendours: If not so; then doubtlesse shee is no more Catholick, then the furious Congregations of Donatists, Arrians, and such like; who
afflicted the true Church against all order of iustice; being neuer able to shew any Catholick predecessours, who maintayned their opinions, nor any lawes made by them to correct the impugners thereof.
That this is the condition of Protestants, I am a witnesse by their disorderly proceeding against the Doctrine, which I deliuered out of the conforme testimonies of the Church.

For wheras it pleased my Caluinian iudges to call it POPISH, erroneous, false, lying, absurd Doctrine; they could not reprooue it otherwayes, then Arrians, and Donatists, that is to say, by reiecting the Fathers, and by a tumultuous processe, without any legall course.

And though I required them to deale with me as with an Heretick, by refelling my doctrine, and by proceeding Canonically against me; yet they oppressed me with authoritie alone; hauing their will for reason, and their power for iustice.

But for asmuch as I haue such abundant proofe for the verity of my doctrine, and that their opinion is condemned in the Churche for no lesse then Heresy, (by Syricius, Bishopp of Rome;Ambros: 10. lib epist: epist. 80. & 81. and a Counsayle there: by S. Ambrose Bishopp of Millayn, and a Counsayle there) I appeach them confidently as Hereticks for embracing Iouinianisme; as Hereticks for contemners
of Antiquity; and therefore as Hereticks culpable of singular pride.

VVhich infamy if they can washe away from themselues by learning, & honesty, then I will retract my sentence, & confesse my selfe to be an Heretick (for the one of vs must needs be Hereticks) howsoeuer euery ingenuous, & indifferent man must needs confesse, that they did not cary themselues as they should haue done to prooue me guilty of this crime.

div.head: The tvveluth Motiue. The superiour Magistrates amonst the Protestants concurre vvith their subordinates, to suppresse the truth, and to oppresse the patrones therof, against all equity, and conscience.
div.p:
THOVGH there be a very nere connexion betwixt the superiour, and inferiour Magistrate, yet since all Magistracy is ordayned for the conseruation of truth, and iustice aswell in the Church, as in the commonwealth (nay much more in the first, then in the second) it is very requisite, that the superiour should yeald redresse, where the inferiour hath done a wrong; and that rather respecting
the cause, then the persons, he should minister equity vnto both with an impartiall hand.

For which consideration, when my petty iudges had oppressed me according to their owne humours, and passions; I appealed vnto my Lord of Canterbury his Grace; in regard of his Academicall soueraignty ouer me, and them (being our honourable Chancellour) and much more in respect of his Archiepiscopall dignity; he being the Primate of our Church; persuading my selfe also, that as he is more high in place, so he would haue bene more equall in iustice; and specially in this cause, since his Grace hath sufficiently manifested himselfe (and hath bene so generally reputed) to be auerse from Caluinisme; Tempora mutant • r, & nos mutamur ini llis. & my hope was, that his present place had not changed his former vnderstanding.

To whom though I truly vnfolded the whole businesse, and acquainted him with all circumstances therunto belonging, yet his Grace seeming to fauour Caluins opiniō (but how cōscionably, it shalbe now referred vnto the iudge of all the world; and he will reueale it in the appointed time) putt me of with continuall delayes.

But his Grace had iust reason to expect a strong resolution in me; since I did appeale vnto him to do me iustice only, & much more
to giue his verdict vpon the Doctrine it selfe. For, otherwayes, no fauour, nor benefit what soeuer could yeald contētment vnto my greiued soule.

I leaue it vnto others to consider, how his Grace standeth affected vnto truth: as for me, I trust, that I haue giuen a sufficient demonstration, on my part, that I would rather loose my liberty of speach, then that shee should want my vttermost defence.

Here the indifferent Reader may also conceiue with me, that if my Doctrine had bene liable vnto a iust censure, then surely his Grace would haue made no stay to condemne it in solemne manner; especially since it was so publiquely taught, so earnestly defended by me; and since I did now entirely desire him to do me iustice without any fauour.

But since this Doctrine was not subiect vnto his condemnation, why then had his Grace so little reuerence vnto the eternall truth of God, and so small respect of me, that he would suffer it to be so indignely censured by his vicegerent, & leaue me helplesse from such iniurious oppression? his pretenses to the contrary (if he haue any) are nothing but smoaky euaporations.

I am nothing, and worse then nothing. But I pleaded for iustice. In what? In a point
of faith. VVhen? being violently oppressed. Before whom? my most proper iudge, to whom the decision of theis things doth most fitly appertayne. For what end? the honour of God, and his gospells sake; which I truly deliuered, and for which I was shame fully intreated.
The testimonies of the Fathers touching Euangelicall Counsayles.

div.head: TO M. DOCTOR KING DEANE OF CHRIST-CHVRCH in Oxford, and Vicechancellour of the Vniuersity, H. L. vvisheth health and saluation in Christ IESVS.
div.p: SIR, though your vvill vvas your lavv to punish me vvithout my offence, yet it shall not be your sanctuary to defend your selfe, vvithout more sufficient reason.

For as you conuented me before a selected Caluinian assembly, so novv I conuent you, and them, before all men in the assured confidence of my good cause, and in the comfortable peace of my sincere heart.

p.hi: And since you dealt vvith me as a Magistrate, by the strength of your authoritie, you must geue me leaue novv to deale vvith you as a Scholler, by the validity of argumēts.

Finally; because I vvish your future happinesse, J cannot omitt to acquaynt you vvith your present misery, vvhich I vvill lay forth before your eyes in Syllogistical manner
and then I vvill referre you vnto the cōsultation of your ovvne heart.

div.p: Whatsoeuer doctrine is founded vpon Scripture, according to the conformable opinion of the ancient Church, that is a point of Catholique faith.
But the doctrine of Euangelicall Counsayles is founded vpon Scripture, according to the conformable opinion of the ancient Church.
Therefore the Doctrine of Euangelicall Counsayles is a point of Catholique faith.

q.p: The Maior is a maxime in all Christian schooles.
The Minor is prooued by the ensuing testimonies of the Fathers: vyhose vniforme verdict in this behalfe is the iudgment of the Church.

div.p: Whosoeuer doth obstinately impugne any point of Catholique faith, he is an heretike.

But Doctour Kinge, D. Aglionby,
D. Airay, D. Hutton, D. Benefield &c. do obstinately impugne a point of Catholique faith.
Therfore D. King, D. Aglionby &c. are heretikes.

q.p: The Maior is granted by all men of iudgment, and is confirmed by S. Augustines rule.De haeres ad Quod vult D. in perorat.
The Minor is prooued by their owne proceedings against me in this particular.

div.p: Euery heretike is bound to recant his heresy, or els he is liable to the punishment, decreed in the Canonicall lavv of the Church.
But D. King, D. Aglionby, &c. are heretikes.
Therfore D. King, D. Aglionby &c. are bound to recant their heresie, or els they are liable to the punishmēt decreed in the Canonicall lavv of the Church.

q.p: The Maior is cleare of it selfe.

div.p:
And because it shal appeare yet more
sensibly, I pray you to consider, that vvhosoeuer reiecteth the ioynt consent of FATHERS in a poynt of doctrine (as D. King doth herein) he is an heretick: and this I vvil briefly declare by foure euidences.
Epist 1. ad Leon. cap. 1.FIRST: by the testimony of Flauianus Patriarch of Constantinople, saying: Haeretici est praecepta Patrum declinare, & instituta eorum despicere.

In Concil. Chalced.SECONDLY: by the testimony of Eudoxius admitted in a general Councel: qui non consentit sacrosanctorum Patrum expositionibus, alienat se ab omni sacerdotali communione, & a Christi praesentia.

See Sozom. l. 7. c. 12.THIRDLY: by the procedings of the most Christian emperour Theodosius against the proud, distracted Hereticks: who would not submitt themselues vnto the iudgements of the venerable Fathers.

See Vincent. Li • . cap. 42.FOVRTHLY: by the practise of the Ephesine Counsayle agaynst Nestorius: vvho vvas iudged an heretick, not onely
in regard of the matter it self, vvherein he erred damnably, but in regard of the manner of triall by the holy Fathers, veterum Interpretum scripta perdiscere de digna • us est. See Socrat. l. 7. c. 32. vvhich his contemptuous spirit did vtterly decline.
