Many also of those Fathers by vvhose testimony the cause was then handled agaynst Nestorius, NOTA are the very same, vvhose verdicts I shall novv produce agaynst D. King, and against his abettours vvhosoeuer.

div.head: An honourable grand-Jury of 24. Fathers, testifying the distinction betwixt Legall Precepts, & EVANGELICALL COVNSAYLES, by their vniforme verdict.
§. 1. FATHERS OF THE LATIN CHVRCH.
div.p: CYPRIANVS (anno Dom. 240.) de discipl. & hab. virg. sect. 17. & 18. Serm. de Natiuit. Christi.OVR Lord doth exhort vs vnto Virginity, but he imposeth not the yoke of necessity. Though mariadge be good, and instituted by God, yet Virginity is more excellent, which the commandement doth not compell vs vnto, but the COVNSAYLE OF PERFECTION doth perswade.

OPTAT. Mileuitan (370) lib 6. contra Parmenian.Virginity is a thing of will, not of necessity. VVherefore S. Paul answered that touching virgins he had no PRECEPT of our Lord; but yet he gaue COVNSAYLE &c.

AMEROSIVS ( • 80) lib. 10. ep. 82.The Apostle doth not cōmand Virginity, but perswade it; for that is not commanded, which is aboue the lavv. No woman is cōpelled
vnto a single life by the authority of any precept, but there are rewards proposed vnto diuers virtues. VVe do not reprehend the one to praise the other, but we praise all, that those things may be preferred, which are chiefest. Mariadge is honourable, but Virginity is more honourable; for he that giueth his virgin in Mariadge, doth vvell; but he that giueth hir not, doth better. VVherefore, that which is good, is not to be auoyded; but that, which is better, is to be preferred. And for this cause Virginity is not imposed, but proposed; whence the Apostle sayeth; Concerning virgins I haue no PRECEPT, but I giue COVNSAYLE. Counsayles are more then Precepts; and therefore when one sayd vnto our Sauiour, all theis things haue I done, (viz. pertayning vnto the law) our Lord answered, & sayd; sell all that thou hast, &c. VVhich was a Counsayle &c.

That which is commanded,HIERO • VMVS (382) contra Ioninian. lib. 1. de verbis Apost. 1 Cor. 7.25. must be performed; and, if we do it not, there is a punishment remayning. For that is commanded in vayn, which is left in the free choyce of him, vnto whom it is commanded. Meruayle not therefore, if, in this prouocatiō of the flesh, the life of Angells be not required of vs, but taught vnto vs. For where Counsayle is giuē, there is the free will of him that offereth; but where a Precept is, there is a necessity in him that obayeth, &c.

Our Lord did not giue a Counsayle, but a Precept vnto vs in his ghospell,AVGVSTINVS; (400) Serm. 61. de Tempore that we should loue our enimyes. A Precept is one thing, but a Counsayle is an other. There is Counsayle giuen to preserue Virginity, to abstayn from wyne, and flesh; to sell our goodes, and to giue them vnto the poore. But to do good, and to decline from euill, and to keepe iustice, it is a Precept. Of Virginity it is sayd; he that can receiue it, let him receiue it; but it is not sayd of iustice; he that can do it, let him do it: for euery tree, that bringeth not forth good fruict, shall be hevven dovvne, and cast into the fire: He that performeth a Counsayle, shall haue the greater glory; but he that keepeth not a Precept, shall be damned, vnlesse he repent. Vide plura in lib. 1. de Adul • erinis coning. cap. 14. de sanctâ Virginitate, cap. 14. &c. Consider also how D. Field doth confesse,Of the Church. pag. 170. that AVGVSTINE is the greatest of all the Fathers, and vvorthiest deuine, that the Church of God euer had since the Apostles times; whose iudgement in this point is conformable vnto the other Fathers, and founded euidently vpon the holy Scripture.

PAVLINVS (4 • 2.) ep. 4. ad Se •• ru Sul • itOur Lord was the good Samaritane, and S. Paul was the Maister of the Inne, who did supererogate, when he added this Counsayle (beyond the Precept) concerning the Virginall estate.

Virginity is not vnder the cōmandement;SEDVLIV • (450.) in 1. Cor. 7. for then Mariadge were forbydden. VVherefore S. Paul had no precept touching Virgins; that being of greater reward, which is offered, and not commanded.
The Apostle had no Precept, EVIGENTIVS (480) in praefat ad Mommum. but he gaue his Counsayle touching Virgins; and hereby he did erogate more then he had receiued.

Some are not iudged, and raigne; who transcend the precepts of the law by a more perfitt vertue, and performe more,GREGOR. Magnus (600.) lib. 26 in Iob. cap. 24. & 25. by a prompt deuotion, then they were obliged vnto. For whereas our Lord sayeth; Go, and sell all that thou hast, All men are bound vnto perfection as farre as the cōdition of their life can permitt • but no man is bound to the cōdition of virginall life. &c. &c. it is not spoken generally vnto all, but, by a speciall commandement, vnto the perfitt. For if it did bynde all men, then it were a sinne to possesse any thinge. But it is one thing, which is prescribed vnto all, and an other thing, which is commanded vnto those, that aspire vnto perfection. Thus Paul preached the gospell freely &c. Vide plura, lib. 15. cap. 19.

The Apostle did supererogate,BEDA (750.) in Luc. 10. when he gaue the Counsayle of Virginity, whereof there is no precept. Likewise; whereas our Lord, did ordayn, that those, who preach the gospell, should liue thereby, S. Paul would not vse that power, &c.

AN •• LMVS (1 ••• .) in 1. Cor 7 25.There is no Precept touching Virgins, but Counsayle onely. Our Lord did not command Virginity, least he might seeme to condemne Mariadge. VVherefore he loueth Virgins more then others, inasmuch as they performe that, where vnto they were not obliged.

BERNARD. (140.) de praecept. & dispens. cap. 10.The rule of S. Bennet is proposed vnto euery man, it is imposed vpon none. It doth profitt, if it be deuoutely vndertaken, & kept; and yet it doth not hurt, if it be not vndertaken. It is a voluntary thing, and not necessary; howbeit, he that doth voluntarily intertayn it, must necessarily retayn it; for he maketh it a necessity vnto himself, inasmuch as euery man is bound to performe his vowes. But that is an happy necessity, which prouoketh vs vnto better thinges.

div.head: §. 2. FATHERS OF THE GREEKE CHVRCH.
div.p: THOSE thinges,ORIGINES (anno Dom. 230) in Rom. cap. 15. which we performe beyond our obligation, we performe not by reason of any precept; as for example. Virginitie is not a debt, which we ought to pay; neither are we commanded thereunto: but we offer it [vnto God] aboue that, which we are bound vnto. For S. Paull sayeth; Concerning Virgins I haue no commandement of our Lord, but I 〈◊〉 coūsaylle.

There are instituted two māners of liuing in the Church of God.EVSEBIV • (330.) de demonstrat. Euangel. lib. 1. cap. 8. The one doth euen exceede our nature, and the cōmon disposition of men: for it desireth not mariadges, nor children, nor welth; but declineth from the vsual life of other men, and our of the singular loue of celestiall thinges, is addicted only vnto the seruice of God. This is a perfit manner of life in Christian Religion.

VVho euer was the author of keeping Virginity? Nay,ATHANASIVS (340.) de Incarnat verbi. He meaneth not that any precept doth impose virginity, but that Christ deliuered his rules. &c. who taught not that this vertue could not be performed? And yet our Sauiour hath bene so powerfull in theis precepts, that children, not ripe for the discipline of lawes, do professe virginity, which is aboue the law,

• A •• LIVS 〈◊〉 ) de 〈◊〉 virgini
• ate.VVe intend not to impose virginity vpon men, by way of Precept, but we insinuate the cleanenes therof vnto such, as purpose to buy the pretious iewell therof. For, concerning virgins, I haue not the precept of our Lord, onely I geue counsaille. God did not appoynt vnto vs a precept of virginity, either in the law, or in the gospel. For he that had instituted Matrimony, and bad men to multiply &c. by what precept could he inioyne virginity? He would not that the merit of so excellent a vertue should be vnder the compasse of a law; but he would haue it to be the tokē of a noble minde, which freely, and without the necessity of a precept, doth, for the desire of vertue, performe that, which surpasseth all the commandements, & is beyond the measure of our humane nature. Mariadge is naturall, but virginity is aboue nature, and is not tyed by the bondes of the law: it offereth vnto God the rare vertue of incorruption, as a pretious gift. Therefore out Lord did no where geue vs a law of virginitie; knowing well, that it is proper vnto a soule, which is addicted vnto the study of vertue. For when he hard one saying; it is not exdient to marry; he (purposing to shew the excellency of virginall estate) answered; all receiue not this saying. And the Apostle (following him) commaundeth those thinges in his epistles,
which are necessary in this life; but he decreeth nothing of virgins. Onely, when he was asked touching this matter, he sayd (in imitation of our Lord) Concerning virgins I haue no precept, but I giue counsayle &c.

In our Christian lawes,NAZIANZ • (380. Orat. 1. in Iulian. some things do impose a necessity of obaying, and they can not be pretermitted without danger.The vvord (lavv) is not taken pre • isely here for a thing imposed, but generally for the • euealed vvil of God. Other thinges bynde vs not with any necessity, but consist in our free will, and choyce. VVherefore if any man keepe them, he shall haue much honour, and reward; and they that fulfill them not, may not feare any perill thereby.

God doth not command impossible thinges;CHRYSOST. (380.) homil. 8. de Poenit. for many do exceede the cōmandements themselues. He doth no where command vs to preserue virginity, and to possesse nothing. VVherefore S. Paul sayeth; Concerning Virgins I haue not any precept from our Lord; onely I giue Counsayle. Thou seest no law here, but an aduise; thou seest him not commanding, but perswading; the first is a matter of necessity, the second of will. I do not command (sayth S. Paul) least I should burthen you; but I giue Counsayle, that I may allure you. Likewyse, concerning Pouerty, there is no commandement: neither did our Lord say simply; sell all that thou hast; but, if thou vvilt be perfitt. If thou performest it, I will crowne thee; if thou doest
not performe it, I will not punish thee. For those things, which are done by commandement, receiue not such recompence: but those things, which are done freely, haue a plentifull reward, &c.

THEODORE • (440.) in i. Cor. 7.25.VVhen the Apostles sayd; if it be so, it is not good to marry: our Sauiour answered; all men receiue not this saying: and agayn: he that can receiue it, let him receiue it. For which cause, the diuine Apostle, S. Paul, sayeth; I haue no precept from our Lord, but I giue Counsayle. I bring no law, but I yeald my aduise, &c.

Abbas (520.) doctr. 1. prope •• ed.VVorthy, and illustrious men do not onely pay yerely tributes, but also they giue free gifts vnto their kinges. Likewyse our Fathers did not onely obserue the due precepts of God, but also they offered vnto him their voluntary gifts; as Virginity, and
• ouerty For theis thinges are gifts; because they are not commanded. Our Lord sayed not vnto the Lawyer; sell all that thou hast, as commanding, but as counselling him. For that particular [if thou vvilt] is the speach of one that giueth Counsayle, and imposeth not a precept. VVherefore our Fathers, with their other virtues, offered vnto God Virginitie, Pouerty &c.

MAXI • VS Monachus ••• 0.) Cen
••• . 4. de Charitate, • up. 67.Those things which we do according to the will of God, are done partly vpon commandement, and partly without, and, as I may
say, by a voluntary oblation. As for example. To loue God, our neighbour, our enimy; not to committ adultery, not to kill &c. theis things cannot be transgressed without condemnation. But Virginitie, Pouerty &c. belong not vnto the commandement; for they are in the nature of gifts.

Christ prescribed not virginity vnto vs,DAMASCEN. ( • 30.) orthodox. fid. lib. 4. cap. 2 •
as promulgating a law (for, according to his saying, all men receiue not this vvord) but he taught it vnto vs indeed, and hath giuen vs power to embrace it.
The Apostle, speaking of virginitie,OECVMEN (1070.) in 1. Cor. 7. doth not deliuer a Precept, but giueth Counsayle.

There are many things,THEOPHYLACT (1071. vid. Baron. Tom. 11. anno Dom. 1071.) In cap. 1. ad Titum. v. 3. which are not commāded, but are left vnto our free choyce; as Pouerty, Virginitie, &c. For our Lord sayeth; he that can, let him receiue it.

div.head: An Aduertisement to the Reader.
div.p: I Desire thee (good Reader) to vnderstand, that I freely offered vnto my aforesayd Iudges, and vnto other learned men in Oxford, and elswhere, to take their choyce of any of theis four reasonable propositions.
FIRST. If I can not approoue, and iustify my Doctrine, by the vniforme consent of all Antiquity, successiuely from the Apostles, I vvill publickly abiure it.
SECOND. If my Iudges can disprooue it by the verdict of any one Oxthodox vvriter, that euer liued in the communion of holy Church, I vvill recant it.
THIRD. Jf I can not prooue that their opinion is heresy, and condemned by the Church, J vvill intertayn it.

FOVRTH. If any article of Religion, accepted by the Church of ENGLAND it self,
and established by vniforme consent, be plainely against my Doctrine, I vvill submitt my self vnto it, and yeald vnto this manner of triall.

p.hi: Theis petitions, & demands (though full of equity) could find no acceptance at my Iudges hands. Consider therefore the quality of theis men, & the goodnes of their Religion: which hauing no conformable grounds, sustayneth it self meerely by fraud, insolency, and oppression.
